The phrase like a polished gem is an example.🔽Just as a crystal, due to the difference in the object it reflects, appears with the form of that object,🔽in the same way, the mind, imbued with the object of perception, enters into meditative attainment on the object and appears with the form of the object. Imbued with the subtle elements,

original: grāhyālambanoparaktaṃ cittaṃ grāhyasamāpannaṃ grāhyasvarūpākāreṇa nirbhāsate / bhūtasūkṣmoparaktaṃ
analyzed: grāhya ālambana uparaktam cittam grāhya samāpannam grāhya svarūpa ākāreṇa nirbhāsate bhūta sūkṣma uparaktam
translated: it enters into meditative attainment on the subtle elements and appears with the form of the subtle elements.

original: bhūtasūkṣmasamāpannaṃ bhūtasūkṣmasvarūpābhāsaṃ bhavati / tathā sthūlālambanoparaktaṃ
analyzed: bhūta sūkṣma samāpannam bhūta sūkṣma svarūpa ābhāsam bhavati tathā sthūla ālambana uparaktam
translated: When absorbed in the subtle elements, it appears in the form of the subtle elements. Similarly, when pervaded by the gross object,

original: sthūlarūpasamāpannaṃ sthūlarūpābhāsaṃ bhavati / tathā viśvabhedoparaktaṃ viśvabhedasamāpannaṃ
analyzed: sthūla rūpa samāpannam sthūla rūpa ābhāsam bhavati tathā viśva bheda uparaktam viśva bheda samāpannam
translated: when absorbed in the gross form, it appears in the form of the gross form. Similarly, when pervaded by the diversity of the universe, when absorbed in the diversity of the universe,

original: viśvarūpābhāsaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: viśva rūpa ābhāsam bhavati
translated: it appears in the form of the universal form.

original: tathā grahaṇeṣv apīndriyeṣv api draṣṭavyam / grahaṇālambanoparaktaṃ grahaṇasamāpannaṃ🔽grahaṇasvarūpākāreṇa nirbhāsate / tathā grahītṛpuruṣālambanoparaktaṃ grahītṛpuruṣasamāpannaṃ
analyzed: tathā grahaṇeṣu api indriyeṣu api draṣṭavyam grahaṇa ālambana uparaktam grahaṇa samāpannam  grahaṇa sva rūpa ākāreṇa nirbhāsate tathā grahītṛ puruṣa ālambana uparaktam grahītṛ puruṣa samāpannam
translated: Similarly, it should be seen in the sense organs also. When pervaded by the object of perception, when absorbed in the perception,🔽it appears in the form of the perceived object. Similarly, when pervaded by the object of the perceiving person, when absorbed in the perceiving person,

original: grahītṛpuruṣasvarūpākāreṇa nirbhāsate / tathā muktapuruṣālambanoparaktaṃ muktapuruṣasamāpannaṃ
analyzed: grahītṛ puruṣa sva rūpa ākāreṇa nirbhāsate tathā mukta puruṣa ālambana uparaktam mukta puruṣa samāpannam
translated: it appears in the form of the perceiving person. Similarly, when pervaded by the object of the liberated person, when absorbed in the liberated person,

original: muktapuruṣasvarūpākāreṇa nirbhāsata iti / tad evam abhijātamaṇikalpasya cetaso grahītṛgrahaṇagrāhyeṣu
analyzed: mukta puruṣa sva rūpa ākāreṇa nirbhāsate iti tat evam abhijāta maṇi kalpasya cetasaḥ grahītṛ grahaṇa grāhyeṣu
translated: it appears in the form of the liberated person. Thus, for the mind which is like a precious gem, in the perceiving person, the sense organs, and the objects,

original: puruṣendriyabhūteṣu yā tatsthatadañjanatā teṣu sthitasya tadākārāpattiḥ sā samāpattir ity ucyate / /
analyzed: puruṣa indriya bhūteṣu yā tad stha tad añjana tā teṣu sthitasya tad ākāra āpattiḥ sā samāpattiḥ iti ucyate
translated: the state of being situated in them and appearing in their form, when situated in them, is called absorption.

original: tatra śabdārthajñānavikalpaiḥ saṃkīrṇā savitarkā samāpattiḥ // / //🔽tadyathā gaur iti śabdo gaur ity artho gaur iti jñānam ity avibhāgena vibhaktānām
analyzed: tatra śabda artha jñāna vikalpaiḥ saṃkīrṇā sa vitarkā samāpattiḥ  tat yathā gauḥ iti śabdaḥ gauḥ iti arthaḥ gauḥ iti jñānam iti avibhāgena vibhaktānām
translated: There, the attainment with discursive thought is mixed with the conceptual thoughts of sound, object, and cognition.🔽For example, it is seen that even when differentiated, the apprehension is as if undifferentiated, as in cow the sound, cow the object, cow the cognition.

original: api grahaṇaṃ dṛṣṭam / vibhajyamānāś cānye śabdadharmā anye 'rthadharmā anye vijñānadharmā
analyzed: api grahaṇam dṛṣṭam vibhajyamānāḥ ca anye śabda dharmāḥ anye rtha dharmāḥ anye vijñāna dharmāḥ
translated: And the properties of sound are different, the properties of the object are different, the properties of cognition are different,

original: ity eteṣāṃ vibhaktaḥ panthāḥ / tatra samāpannasya yogino yo gavādyarthaḥ samādhiprajñāyāṃ
analyzed: iti eteṣām vibhaktaḥ panthāḥ tatra samāpannasya yoginaḥ yaḥ gavādi arthaḥ samādhi prajñāyām
translated: when they are differentiated. There, for the yogi who has attained, the object such as a cow, which is mounted on the wisdom of concentration,

original: samārūḍhaḥ sa cec chabdārthajñānavikalpānuviddha upāvartate sā saṃkīrṇā samāpattiḥ
analyzed: samārūḍhaḥ sa ced śabda artha jñāna vikalpa anuviddhaḥ upāvartate sā saṃkīrṇā samāpattiḥ
translated: if it occurs mixed with the conceptual thoughts of sound, object, and cognition, that is a mixed attainment.

original: savitarkety ucyate / /
analyzed: sa vitarkā iti ucyate
translated: It is called with discursive thought.

original: yadā punaḥ śabdasaṃketasmṛtipariśuddhau śrutānumānajñānavikalpaśūnyāyāṃ samādhiprajñāyāṃ
analyzed: yadā punar śabda saṃketa smṛti pariśuddhau śruta anumāna jñāna vikalpa śūnyāyām samādhi prajñāyām
translated: But when, in the purification of the memory of the conventional connection with sound, in the wisdom of concentration devoid of the conceptual thoughts of hearing and inference,

original: svarūpamātreṇāvasthito 'rthas tatsvarūpākāramātratayaivāvacchidyate / sā ca nirvitarkā
analyzed: sva rūpa mātreṇa avasthitaḥ rthaḥ tad sva rūpa ākāra mātra tayā eva avacchidyate sā ca nirvitarkā
translated: the object abides merely in its own form, and it is delimited merely by the form of its own nature, and that is the attainment without discursive thought,

original: samāpattiḥ / tat paraṃ pratyakṣam / tac ca śrutānumānayor bījam / tataḥ śrutānumāne
analyzed: samāpattiḥ tat param pratyakṣam tat ca śruta anumānayoḥ bījam tatas śruta anumāne
translated: that is the highest perception, and that is the seed of hearing and inference. From that, hearing and inference,

original: prabhavataḥ / na ca śrutānumānajñānasahabhūtaṃ tad darśanam / tasmād asaṃkīrṇaṃ praṃmāṇāntareṇa🔽yogino nirvitarkasamādhijaṃ darśanam iti / nirvitarkāyāḥ samāpatter asyāḥ sūtreṇa
analyzed: prabhavataḥ na ca śruta anumāna jñāna saha bhūtam tat darśanam tasmāt asaṃkīrṇam praṃmāṇa antareṇa  yoginaḥ nirvitarka samādhi jam darśanam iti nirvitarkāyāḥ samāpatteḥ asyāḥ sūtreṇa
translated: It is from the source. And that vision is not accompanied by heard or inferred knowledge. Therefore, it is not mixed with another means of knowledge.

original: lakṣaṇaṃ dyotyate
analyzed: lakṣaṇam dyotyate
translated: The vision of the yogi born from the concentration without discursive thought is thus. The definition of this concentration without discursive thought is indicated by the sutra:

original: smṛtipariśuddhau svarūpaśūnyevārthamātranirbhāsā nirvitarkā // / //
analyzed: smṛti pariśuddhau sva rūpa śūnyā iva artha mātra nirbhāsā nirvitarkā
translated: When mindfulness is pure, it is devoid of its own form and appears only as the object, without discursive thought.

original: yā śabdasaṃketaśrutānumānajñānavikalpasmṛtipariśuddhau grāhyasvarūpa /uparaktā prajñā🔽svam iva prajñāsvarūpaṃ grahaṇātmakaṃ tyaktvā padārthamātrasvarūpā grāhyasvarūpāpanneva
analyzed: yā śabda saṃketa śruta anumāna jñāna vikalpa smṛti pariśuddhau grāhya sva rūpa auparaktā prajñā  svam iva prajñā svarūpam grahaṇa ātmakam tyaktvā padārtha mātra svarūpā grāhya svarūpa āpannā iva
translated: When the wisdom that is purified of the conceptual thoughts of hearing, inferring, and remembering words and conventions is devoid of the form of the object to be grasped,🔽having abandoned its own form of grasping, which is the nature of wisdom,

original: bhavati sā tadā nirvitarkā samāpattiḥ /
analyzed: bhavati sā tadā nirvitarkā samāpattiḥ
translated: it becomes only the form of the object, which has taken on the form of the object to be grasped. At that time, it is the concentration without discursive thought.

original: tathā ca vyākyātaṃ tasyā ekabuddhyupakramo hy arthātmāṇupracayaviśeṣātmā gavādir ghaṭādir vā lokaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ca vyākyātam tasyāḥ eka buddhi upakramaḥ hi artha ātma aṇu pracaya viśeṣa ātmā gavādiḥ ghaṭa ādiḥ vā lokaḥ
translated: And it is explained like this: For the world, which consists of cows, pots, etc., which is the collection of atoms grasped by a single cognition, is the nature of a particular arrangement of atoms.

original: sa ca saṃsthānaviśeṣo bhūtasūkṣmāṇāṃ sādhāraṇo dharma ātmabhūtaḥ phalena vyaktenānumitaḥ
analyzed: sa ca saṃsthāna viśeṣaḥ bhūta sūkṣmāṇām sādhāraṇaḥ dharmaḥ ātma bhūtaḥ phalena vyaktena anumitaḥ
translated: And that particular arrangement is a general property of the subtle elements, which is the nature of the effect, inferred by the manifest.

original: svavyañjakāñjanaḥ prādurbhavati / dharmāntarasya kapālāder udaye ca tirobhavati / sa
analyzed: sva vyañjaka añjanaḥ prādurbhavati dharma antarasya kapāla ādeḥ udaye ca tirobhavati sa
translated: The manifestor of its own form appears. And when another dharma, such as a skull, arises, it disappears.

original: eṣa dharmo 'vayavīty ucyate / yo 'sāv ekaś ca mahāṃś cāṇīṃyaś ca sparśavāṃś ca kriyādharmakaś
analyzed: eṣa dharmaḥ vayavī iti ucyate saḥ au ekaḥ ca mahān ca aṇīṃyaḥ ca sparśavān ca kriyā dharmakaḥ
translated: That is called the whole. It is one, large, small, tangible, has the property of action,

original: cānityaś ca tenāvayavinā vyavahārāḥ kriyante /
analyzed: ca anityaḥ ca tena avayavinā vyavahārāḥ kriyante
translated: and is impermanent. Transactions are carried out with that whole.

original: yasya punar avastukaḥ sa pracayaviśeṣaḥ / sūkṣmaṃ ca kāraṇam anupalabhyam avikalpasya
analyzed: yasya punar avastukaḥ sa pracaya viśeṣaḥ sūkṣmam ca kāraṇam an upalabhyam a vikalpasya
translated: But for one for whom that aggregation is unreal, and the subtle cause is imperceptible to non-conceptual [perception],

original: tasyāvayavyabhāvād atadrūpapratiṣṭhaṃ mithyājñānam iti prāyeṇa sarvam eva prāptaṃ
analyzed: tasya avayavi abhāvāt a tad rūpa pratiṣṭham mithyājñānam iti prāyeṇa sarvam eva prāptam
translated: since there is no whole for him, that [perception] is false knowledge not based on that form. Thus almost all [perception] is

original: mithyājñānam iti / tadā ca samyagjñānam api kiṃ syād viṣayābhāvāt / yad yad upalabhyate🔽tat tad avayavitvenāmnātam / tasmād asty avayavī yo mahattvādivyavahārāpannaḥ samāpatter
analyzed: mithyā jñānam iti tadā ca samyak jñānam api kim syāt viṣaya abhāvāt yat yat upalabhyate  tat tat avayavi tvena āmnātam tasmāt asti avayavī yaḥ mahat tva ādi vyavahāra āpannaḥ samāpatteḥ
translated: false knowledge. And then what could right knowledge be, since there is no object? Whatever is perceived🔽is said to be whole. Therefore there is a whole that becomes the object of the attainment

original: nirvitarkāyā viṣayī bhavati / /
analyzed: nirvitarkāyāḥ viṣayī bhavati
translated: of the trance state free from discursive thought, which is subject to transactions such as largeness.

original: etayaiva savicārā nirvicārā ca sūkṣmaviṣayā vyākhyātā // / //
analyzed: etayā eva sa vicārā nirvicārā ca sūkṣma viṣayā vyākhyātā
translated: By this very [explanation] the discursive and non-discursive [trance states] are explained as having subtle objects.

original: tatra bhūtasūkṣmakeṣv abhivyaktadharmakeṣu deśakālanimittānubhavāvacchinneṣu yā samāpattiḥ
analyzed: tatra bhūta sūkṣmakeṣu abhivyakta dharmakeṣu deśa kāla nimitta anubhava avacchinneṣu yā samāpattiḥ
translated: There, the attainment in the subtle elements, which have manifest properties, and are delimited by the experience of place, time, and cause,

original: sā savicārety ucyate / tatrāpy ekabuddhinirgrāhyam evoditadharmaviśiṣṭaṃ bhūtasūkṣmam
analyzed: sā sa vicārā iti ucyate tatra api eka buddhi nirgrāhyam evā udita dharma viśiṣṭam bhūta sūkṣmam
translated: is called with discursive thought. Even there, the subtle element, which has manifest properties, and is grasped by a single cognition,

original: ālambanībhūtaṃ samādhiprajñāyām upatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: ālambanībhūtam samādhi prajñāyām upatiṣṭhate
translated: appears as the object of the concentration-wisdom.

original: yā punaḥ sarvathā sarvataḥ śāntoditāvyapadeśyadharmānavacchinneṣu sarvadharmānupātiṣu
analyzed: yā punar sarvathā sarvatas śānta udita avyapadeśya dharma anavacchinneṣu sarva dharma anupātiṣu
translated: But the attainment in those which are not delimited by the properties of peace, rise, and inexpressibility in any way and from any direction, which follow all dharmas,

original: sarvadharmātmakeṣu samāpattiḥ sā nirvicārety ucyate / evaṃsvarūpaṃ hi tadbhūtasūkṣmam
analyzed: sarva dharma ātmakeṣu samāpattiḥ sā nirvicārā iti ucyate evaṃsvarūpam hi tat bhūta sūkṣmam
translated: and which have the nature of all dharmas, is called without discursive thought. For such is the nature of that subtle element.

original: etenaiva svarūpeṇālambanībhūtam eva samādhiprajñāsvarūpam uparañjayati /
analyzed: etena eva sva rūpeṇa ālambanībhūtam eva samādhi prajñā sva rūpam uparañjayati
translated: It appears as the object in that very nature, and colors the nature of the concentration-wisdom.

original: prajñā ca svarūpaśūnyevārthamātrā yadā bhavati tadā nirvicārety ucyate / tatra mahadvastuviṣayā savitarkā nirvitarkā ca /
analyzed: prajñā ca sva rūpa śūnyā iva artha mātrā yadā bhavati tadā nirvicārā iti ucyate tatra mahat vastu viṣayā sa vitarkā nirvitarkā ca
translated: And when wisdom becomes mere object, empty of its own nature, then it is called without discursive thought. There, the one with discursive thought and without discursive thought has the great thing as its object.

original: sūkṣmavastuviṣayā savicārā nirvicārā ca / evam ubhayor etayaiva nirvitarkayā vikalpahānir vyākhyāteti / /
analyzed: sūkṣma vastu viṣayā sa vicārā nirvicārā ca evam ubhayoḥ etayā eva nirvitarkayā vikalpa hāniḥ vyākhyātā iti
translated: The one with investigation and without investigation has the subtle thing as its object. Thus, the loss of conceptualization by both is explained by this very one without discursive thought.

original: sūkṣmaviṣayatvaṃ cāliṅgaparyavasānam // / //🔽pārthivasyāṇor gandhatanmātraṃ sūkṣmo viṣayaḥ / āpyasya rasatanmātram / taijasasya
analyzed: sūkṣma viṣaya tvam ca aliṅga paryavasānam  pārthivasya aṇoḥ gandha tanmātram sūkṣmaḥ viṣayaḥ āpyasya rasa tanmātram taijasasya
translated: And the object of the subtle is the end of the non-manifest.

original: rūpatanmātram / vāyavīyasya sparśatanmātram / ākāśasya śabdatanmātram iti / teṣām ahaṃkāraḥ /🔽asyāpi liṅgamātraṃ sūkṣmo viṣayaḥ / liṅgamātrasyāpy aliṅgaṃ sūkṣmo viṣayaḥ / na cāliṅgāt
analyzed: rūpa tanmātram vāyavīyasya sparśa tanmātram ākāśasya śabda tanmātram iti teṣām ahaṃkāraḥ  asya api liṅga mātram sūkṣmaḥ viṣayaḥ liṅga mātrasya api aliṅgam sūkṣmaḥ viṣayaḥ na ca aliṅgāt
translated: The subtle object of the earth atom is the subtle element of smell. Of the water [atom] it is the subtle element of taste. Of the fire [atom] it is the subtle element of form. Of the air [atom] it is the subtle element of touch. Of space it is the subtle element of sound. Of those [five subtle elements] the subtle object is ego.🔽The subtle object of that [ego] is the manifest alone. The subtle object of the manifest alone is the non-manifest. And beyond the non-manifest there is nothing more subtle.

original: paraṃ sūkṣmam asti / nanv asti puruṣaḥ sūkṣma iti satyam / yathā liṅgāt param aliṅgasya
analyzed: param sūkṣmam asti nanu asti puruṣaḥ sūkṣmaḥ iti satyam yathā liṅgāt param aliṅgasya
translated: But is there not the subtle soul? It is true. As the non-manifest is more subtle than the manifest,

original: saukṣmyaṃ na caivaṃ puruṣasya / kiṃtu /
analyzed: saukṣmyam na ca evam puruṣasya kiṃtu
translated: but the soul is not like that. Rather,

original: liṅgasyānvayikāraṇaṃ puruṣo na bhavati /
analyzed: liṅgasya anvayi kāraṇam puruṣaḥ na bhavati
translated: the soul is not the continuing cause of the manifest.

original: hetus tu bhavatīti / ataḥ pradhāne saukṣmyaṃ niratiśayaṃ vyākhyātam / /
analyzed: hetuḥ tu bhavati iti atas pradhāne saukṣmyam niratiśayam vyākhyātam
translated: But it is the cause. Therefore, subtlety is explained as supreme in primordial matter.

original: tā eva sabījaḥ samādhiḥ // / //
analyzed: tāḥ eva sa bījaḥ samādhiḥ
translated: Those [four states of consciousness] are with seed, the concentration [of the mind].

original: tāś catasraḥ samāpattayo bahirvastubījā iti samādhir api sabījaḥ / tatra sthūle 'rthe savitarko nirvitarkaḥ /
analyzed: tāḥ catasraḥ samāpattayaḥ bahis vastu bījāḥ iti samādhiḥ api sa bījaḥ tatra sthūle rthe sa vitarkaḥ nirvitarkaḥ
translated: And those four states of concentration have external objects as seeds, so concentration is also with seed. There, in a gross object, [concentration] is with vitarka and without vitarka.

original: sūkṣme 'rthe savicāro nirvicāra iti caturdhopasaṃkhyātaḥ samādhir iti / /
analyzed: sūkṣme rthe sa vicāraḥ nirvicāraḥ iti caturdhā upasaṃkhyātaḥ samādhiḥ iti
translated: The concentration that is mentioned as fourfold in the sutra, namely, with applied thought and sustained thought, without applied thought but with sustained thought, and so on, is included in this.

original: nirvicāravaiśāradye 'dhyātmaprasādaḥ // / //
translated: In the absence of applied thought and sustained thought, there is serenity, faith, and so on.

original: aśuddhyāvaraṇamalāpetasya prakāśātmano buddhisattvasya rajastamobhyām anabhibhūtaḥ
analyzed: aśuddhi āvaraṇa mala apetasya prakāśa ātmanaḥ buddhi sattvasya rajaḥ tamobhyām an abhibhūtaḥ
translated: When the mind is free from the impurities of the obscurations of impurity, the flow of the pure state of the mind, which is of the nature of light, is not overwhelmed by rajas and tamas,

original: svacchaḥ sthitipravāho vaiśāradyam / yadā nirvicārasya samādher vaiśāradyam idaṃ jāyate
analyzed: svacchaḥ sthiti pravāhaḥ vaiśāradyam yadā nirvicārasya samādheḥ vaiśāradyam idam jāyate
translated: it becomes clear. This clarity is serenity. When there is serenity in the absence of applied thought and sustained thought,

original: tadā yogino bhavaty adhyātmaprasādo bhūtārthaviṣayaḥ kramānanurodhī sphuṭaḥ prajñālokaḥ /
analyzed: tadā yoginaḥ bhavati adhyātma prasādaḥ bhūta artha viṣayaḥ krama an anurodhī sphuṭaḥ prajñā ālokaḥ
translated: then the yogi attains inner serenity, which is a clear light of wisdom that is not dependent on sequence and has as its object the true nature of things.

original: tathā coktam prajñāprasādam āruhya aśocyaḥ śocato janān /
analyzed: tathā ca uktam prajñā prasādam āruhya aśocyaḥ śocataḥ janān
translated: And it is said: Having ascended to the clarity of wisdom, one who is not to be grieved should grieve for people who are to be grieved.

original: bhūmiṣṭhān iva śailasthaḥ sarvān prājño 'nupaśyati / /
analyzed: bhūmiṣṭhān iva śaila sthaḥ sarvān prājñaḥ nupaśyati
translated: Like one standing on a mountain peak, the wise one sees all those standing on the ground.

original: ṛtaṃbharā tatra prajñā // / //
analyzed: ṛtaṃbharā tatra prajñā
translated: The wisdom there is supported by truth.

original: tasmin samāhitacittasya yā prajñā jāyate tasyā ṛtaṃbhareti saṃjñā bhavati / anvarthā ca sā /
analyzed: tasmin samāhita cittasya yā prajñā jāyate tasyāḥ ṛtaṃbhara iti saṃjñā bhavati anvarthā ca sā
translated: The wisdom that arises in one whose mind is concentrated on that is called supported by truth. And it is meaningful.

original: satyam eva bibharti na ca tatra viparyāsajñānagandho 'py astīti / tathā coktam
analyzed: satyam eva bibharti na ca tatra viparyāsa jñāna gandhaḥ api asti iti tathā ca uktam
translated: It supports only the truth, and there is not even a trace of the knowledge of error there. And it is said:

original: āgamenānumānena dhyānābhyāsarasena ca /
analyzed: āgamena anumānena dhyāna abhyāsa rasena ca
translated: By scripture, by inference, and by the delight of meditative practice,

original: tridhā prakalpayan prajñāṃ labhate yogam uttamam iti / /
analyzed: tridhā prakalpayan prajñām labhate yogam uttamam iti
translated: contemplating wisdom in three ways, one attains the highest yoga.

original: sā punaḥ
analyzed: sā punar
translated: Moreover,

original: śrutānumānaprajñābhyām anyaviṣayā viśeṣārthatvāt // / //
analyzed: śruta anumāna prajñābhyām anya viṣayāḥ viśeṣa artha tvāt
translated: it has a different object from the wisdom of hearing and inference, because it has a specific purpose.

original: śrutam āgamavijñānaṃ tat sāmānyaviṣayam / na hy āgamena śakyo viśeṣo 'bhidhātum /
analyzed: śrutam āgama vijñānam tat sāmānya viṣayam na hi āgamena śakyaḥ viśeṣaḥ abhidhātum
translated: Hearing is the knowledge of scripture, and that has a general object. For a specific [object] cannot be expressed by scripture.

original: kasmāt /
analyzed: kasmāt
translated: Why is that?

original: na hi viśeṣeṇa kṛtasaṃketaḥ śabda iti / tathānumānaṃ sāmānyaviṣayam eva / yatra prāptis
analyzed: na hi viśeṣeṇa kṛta saṃketaḥ śabdaḥ iti tathā anumānam sāmānya viṣayam eva yatra prāptiḥ
translated: Because a word is not conventionally established with a specific [object]. Similarly, inference has only a general object. Where there is attainment,

original: tatra gatir yatrāprāptis tatra na bhavati gatir ity uktam / anumānena ca sāmānyenopasaṃhāraḥ /
analyzed: tatra gatiḥ yatra aprāptiḥ tatra na bhavati gatiḥ iti uktam anumānena ca sāmānyena upasaṃhāraḥ
translated: there is movement. Where there is no attainment, there is no movement. And by inference, there is a conclusion with a general [object].

original: tasmāc chrutānumānaviṣayo na viśeṣaḥ kaścid astīti /
analyzed: tasmāt śruta anumāna viṣayaḥ na viśeṣaḥ kaścid asti iti
translated: Therefore, there is no specific [object] whatsoever that is the object of hearing and inference.

original: na cāsya sūkṣmavyavahitaviprakṛṣṭasya vastuno lokapratyakṣeṇa grahaṇam asti / na cāsya
analyzed: na ca asya sūkṣma vyavahita viprakṛṣṭasya vastunaḥ loka pratyakṣeṇa grahaṇam asti na ca asya
translated: And that subtle, concealed, or distant object is not apprehended by worldly direct perception. And

original: viśeṣasyāpramāṇakasyābhāvo 'stīti samādhiprajñānirgrāhya eva sa viśeṣo bhavati bhūtasūkṣmagato
analyzed: viśeṣasya apramāṇakasya abhāvaḥ sti iti samādhi prajñā nirgrāhyaḥ eva sa viśeṣaḥ bhavati bhūta sūkṣma gataḥ
translated: since that specific [object] does not exist without a means of knowledge, that specific [object] which exists in the subtle elements is indeed to be grasped by the wisdom of meditative concentration.

original: vā puruṣagato vā / tasmāc chrutānumānaprajñābhyām anyaviṣayā sā prajñā viśeṣārthatvād iti / /
analyzed: vā puruṣa gataḥ vā tasmāt śruta anumāna prajñābhyām anya viṣayā sā prajñā viśeṣa artha tvāt iti
translated: Therefore, that wisdom has a different object from the wisdoms of hearing and inference, because it has a specific purpose.

original: samādhiprajñāpratilambhe yoginaḥ prajñākṛtaḥ saṃskāro navo navo jāyate
analyzed: samādhi prajñā pratilambhe yoginaḥ prajñā kṛtaḥ saṃskāraḥ navaḥ navaḥ jāyate
translated: When the yogi attains the wisdom of concentration, a new impression created by wisdom is born anew.

original: tajjaḥ saṃskāro 'nyasaṃskārapratibandhī // / //
analyzed: tad jaḥ saṃskāraḥ nya saṃskāra pratibandhī
translated: That impression born from it obstructs other impressions.

original: samādhiprajñāprabhavaḥ saṃskāro vyutthānasaṃskārāśayaṃ bādhate / vyutthānasaṃskārābhibhavāt
analyzed: samādhi prajñā prabhavaḥ saṃskāraḥ vyutthāna saṃskāra āśayam bādhate vyutthāna saṃskāra abhibhavāt
translated: The impression born from the wisdom of concentration overpowers the tendency of the impressions of discursive thought. Due to the suppression of the impressions of discursive thought,

original: tatprabhavāḥ pratyayā na bhavanti / pratyayanirodhe samādhir upatiṣṭhate / tataḥ samādhijā prajñā /
analyzed: tad prabhavāḥ pratyayāḥ na bhavanti pratyaya nirodhe samādhiḥ upatiṣṭhate tatas samādhi jā prajñā
translated: the conditions born from that do not arise. When the conditions cease, concentration is established. Then there is wisdom born from concentration.

original: tataḥ prajñākṛtāḥ saṃskārā iti navo navaḥ saṃskārāśayo jāyate / tataś ca prajñā /
analyzed: tatas prajñā kṛtāḥ saṃskārāḥ iti navaḥ navaḥ saṃskāra āśayaḥ jāyate tatas ca prajñā
translated: Then there are impressions created by wisdom. Thus a new tendency of impressions is born, and from that there is wisdom.

original: tataś ca saṃskārā iti / katham asau saṃskārātiśayaś cittaṃ sādhikāraṃ na kariṣyatīti /
analyzed: tatas ca saṃskārāḥ iti katham asau saṃskāra atiśayaḥ cittam sādhikāram na kariṣyati iti
translated: And from that there are impressions. How will that excess of impressions not make the mind with a special function?

original: na te prajñākṛtāḥ saṃskārāḥ kleśakṣayahetutvāc cittam adhikāraviśiṣṭaṃ kurvanti /
analyzed: na te prajñā kṛtāḥ saṃskārāḥ kleśa kṣaya hetu tvāt cittam adhikāra viśiṣṭam kurvanti
translated: Those impressions created by wisdom do not make the mind with a special function, because they are the cause of the destruction of afflictions.

original: cittaṃ hi te svakāryād avasādayanti / khyātiparyavasānaṃ hi cittaceṣṭitam iti / /
analyzed: cittam hi te sva kāryāt avasādayanti khyāti paryavasānam hi citta ceṣṭitam iti
translated: For they cause your mind to fall away from its own function. For the activity of the mind ends in manifestation.

original: kiṃ cāsya bhavati
analyzed: kim ca asya bhavati
translated: What happens to him?

original: tasyāpi nirodhe sarvanirodhān nirbījaḥ samādhiḥ // / //
analyzed: tasya api nirodhe sarva nirodhāt nirbījaḥ samādhiḥ
translated: When that [mind of cessation] also ceases, due to the cessation of everything, the seedless concentration...

original: sa na kevalaṃ samādhiprajñāvirodhī prajñākṛtānām api saṃskārāṇāṃ pratibandhī bhavati / kasmāt /
analyzed: sa na kevalam samādhi prajñā virodhī prajñā kṛtānām api saṃskārāṇām pratibandhī bhavati kasmāt
translated: It is not only an opponent of concentration wisdom, but also an opponent of the formations produced by wisdom. Why is that?

original: nirodhajaḥ saṃskāraḥ samādhijān saṃskārān bādhata iti /🔽nirodhasthitikālakramānubhavena nirodhacittakṛtasaṃskārāstitvam anumeyam / vyutthānanirodhasamādhiprabhavaiḥ
analyzed: nirodha jaḥ saṃskāraḥ samādhi jān saṃskārān bādhate iti  nirodha sthiti kāla krama anubhavena nirodha citta kṛta saṃskāra astitvam anumeyam vyutthāna nirodha samādhi prabhavaiḥ
translated: The formation born of cessation obstructs the formations born of concentration.🔽The existence of the formations produced by the mind of cessation is to be inferred through the experience of the sequence of the duration of cessation.

original: saha kaivalyabhāgīyaiḥ saṃskāraiś cittaṃ svasyāṃ prakṛtāv avasthitāyāṃ pravilīyate /
analyzed: saha kaivalya bhāgīyaiḥ saṃskāraiḥ cittam svasyām prakṛtau avasthitāyām pravilīyate
translated: Along with the formations belonging to the part of isolation produced by the concentration of cessation and the concentration of emergence, the mind dissolves into its own inherent nature that has been established.

original: tasmāt te saṃskārāś cittasyādhikāravirodhino na sthitihetavo bhavantīti / yasmād avasitādhikāraṃ
analyzed: tasmāt te saṃskārāḥ cittasya adhikāra virodhinaḥ na sthiti hetavaḥ bhavanti iti yasmāt avasita adhikāram
translated: Therefore, those formations are opponents of the mind's authority, and are not causes of its duration. Because the mind,

original: saha kaivalyabhāgīyaiḥ saṃskāraiś cittaṃ nivartate /
analyzed: saha kaivalya bhāgīyaiḥ saṃskāraiḥ cittam nivartate
translated: along with the formations belonging to the part of isolation, turns back when its authority has ended.

original: tasmin nivṛtte puruṣaḥ svarūpamātrapratiṣṭho 'taḥ śuddhaḥ kevalo mukta ity ucyata iti / /
analyzed: tasmin nivṛtte puruṣaḥ sva rūpa mātra pratiṣṭhā u taḥ śuddhaḥ kevalaḥ muktaḥ iti ucyate iti
translated: When that has ceased, the person abides in his own nature alone. Therefore, he is said to be pure, solitary, and liberated.

original: iti śrīpātañjale sāṃkhyapravacane yogaśāstre śrīmadvyāsabhāṣye prathamaḥ samādhipādaḥ /
analyzed: iti śrī pātañjale sāṃkhyapravacane yoga śāstre śrīmat vyāsa bhāṣye prathamaḥ samādhi pādaḥ
translated: Thus ends the first chapter on concentration in the Yoga treatise of Patanjali, expounded by the revered Vyasa, in the Sankhya teaching.

original: uddiṣṭaḥ samāhitacittasya yogaḥ / kathaṃ vyutthitacitto 'pi yogayuktaḥ syād ity etad ārabhyate
analyzed: uddiṣṭaḥ samāhita cittasya yogaḥ katham vyutthita cittaḥ api yoga yuktaḥ syāt iti etat ārabhyate
translated: Yoga has been taught for one whose mind is concentrated. How can one whose mind is distracted also be engaged in yoga? This is begun.

original: tapaḥsvādhyāyeśvarapraṇidhānāni kriyāyogaḥ // / //🔽nātapasvino yogaḥ sidhyati / anādikarmakleśavāsanācitrā pratyupasthitaviṣayajālā cāśuddhir
analyzed: tapaḥ svādhyāya īśvara praṇidhānāni kriyā yogaḥ  na atapasvinaḥ yogaḥ sidhyati anādi karma kleśa vāsanā citrā pratyupasthita viṣaya jālā ca aśuddhiḥ
translated: Austerity, self-study, and devotion to God are the yoga of action.🔽Yoga does not succeed for one who is not an ascetic. Impurity, variegated with the impressions of beginningless actions and afflictions, and the net of present objects,

original: nāntareṇa tapaḥ saṃbhedam āpadyata iti tapasa upādānam / tac ca cittaprasādanam abādhamānam
analyzed: na antareṇa tapaḥ saṃbhedam āpadyate iti tapasaḥ upādānam tat ca citta prasādanam a bādhamānam
translated: cannot be destroyed without austerity. Therefore, austerity is adopted. And that, which purifies the mind without obstruction,

original: anenāsevyam iti manyate /
analyzed: anena āsevyam iti manyate
translated: is considered to be to be practiced by this (means).

original: svādhyāyaḥ praṇavādipavitrāṇāṃ japo mokṣaśāstrādhyayanaṃ vā / īśvarapraṇidhānaṃ sarvakriyāṇāṃ paramagurāv arpaṇaṃ tatphalasaṃnyāso vā / /
analyzed: svādhyāyaḥ praṇava ādi pavitrāṇām japaḥ mokṣa śāstra adhyayanam vā īśvara praṇidhānam sarva kriyāṇām parama gurau arpaṇam tad phala saṃnyāsaḥ vā
translated: Self-study is the repetition of the Pranava and other purifying mantras, or the study of the scriptures on liberation. Devotion to God is the dedication of all actions to the supreme teacher, or the renunciation of their fruits.

original: sa hi kriyāyogaḥ
analyzed: sa hi kriyā yogaḥ
translated: That is the yoga of action.

original: samādhibhāvanārthaḥ kleśatanūkaraṇārthaś ca // / //
analyzed: samādhi bhāvanā arthaḥ kleśa tanūkaraṇa arthaḥ ca
translated: [It serves] the purpose of cultivating concentration and weakening the afflictions.

original: sa hy āsevyamānaḥ samādhiṃ bhāvayati kleśāṃś ca pratanūkaroti / pratanūkṛtān kleśān
analyzed: sa hi āsevyamānaḥ samādhim bhāvayati kleśān ca pratanūkaroti pratanūkṛtān kleśān
translated: For when it is practiced, it cultivates concentration and weakens the afflictions. Having weakened the afflictions,

original: prasaṃkhyānāgninā dagdhabījakalpān aprasavadharmiṇaḥ kariṣyatīti / teṣāṃ tanūkaraṇāt🔽punaḥ kleśair aparāmṛṣṭā sattvapuruṣānyatāmātrakhyātiḥ sūkṣmā prajñā samāptādhikārā
analyzed: prasaṃkhyāna agninā dagdha bīja kalpān aprasava dharmiṇaḥ kariṣyati iti teṣām tanūkaraṇāt  punar kleśaiḥ a parāmṛṣṭā sattva puruṣa anya tā mātra khyātiḥ sūkṣmā prajñā samāpta adhikārā
translated: it will make them incapable of producing results by burning their seeds with the fire of discernment. Because it weakens them,

original: pratiprasavāya kalpiṣyata iti / /
analyzed: pratiprasavāya kalpiṣyate iti
translated: the subtle wisdom that merely cognizes the difference between the self and the person, untouched by the afflictions, will be sufficient for the completion of one's duties.

original: atha ke kleśāḥ kiyanto veti
analyzed: atha ke kleśāḥ kiyantaḥ vā iti
translated: Now, what are the afflictions and how many are there?

original: avidyāsmitārāgadveṣābhiniveśāḥ kleśāḥ // / //
analyzed: avidyā asmitā rāga dveṣa abhiniveśāḥ kleśāḥ
translated: The afflictions are ignorance, pride, attachment, aversion, and clinging.

original: kleśā iti pañca viparyayā ity arthaḥ / te spandamānā guṇādhikāraṃ draḍhayanti /
analyzed: kleśāḥ iti pañca viparyayāḥ iti arthaḥ te spandamānāḥ guṇa adhikāram draḍhayanti
translated: The afflictions are the five inversions, that is the meaning. When they are agitated, they strengthen the operation of the qualities.

original: pariṇāmam avasthāpayanti /🔽kāryakāraṇasrota unnamayanti /
analyzed: pariṇāmam avasthāpayanti  kārya kāraṇa srotaḥ unnamayanti
translated: They establish the transformation [of consciousness].🔽They elevate the stream of effects and causes.

original: parasparānugrahatantrībhūtvā karmavipākaṃ cābhinirharantīti / /
analyzed: paraspara anugraha tantrī bhūtvā karma vipākam ca abhinirharanti iti
translated: Having become the thread of mutual support, they also bring about the ripening of karma.

original: avidyā kṣetram uttareṣāṃ prasuptatanuvicchinnodārāṇām // / //
analyzed: avidyā kṣetram uttareṣām prasupta tanu vicchinna udārāṇām
translated: Ignorance is the field for the others, whether dormant, weak, interrupted, or strong.

original: atrāvidyā kṣetraṃ prasavabhūmir uttarareṣām asmitādīnāṃ caturvidhavikalpānāṃ prasuptatanuvicchinnodārāṇām /
analyzed: atra avidyā kṣetram prasava bhūmiḥ uttara reṣām asmitā ādīnām caturvidha vikalpānām prasupta tanu vicchinna udārāṇām
translated: Here, ignorance is the field, the place of origin, of these four kinds of conceptual thoughts beginning with self-identification, which are dormant, weak, interrupted, and lofty.

original: tatra kā prasuptiḥ / cetasi śaktimātrapratiṣṭhānāṃ bījabhāvopagamaḥ / tasya prabodha
analyzed: tatra kā prasuptiḥ cetasi śakti mātra pratiṣṭhānām bīja bhāva upagamaḥ tasya prabodha
translated: What is dormancy there? It is the state of seeds for those that are established as mere potentialities in the mind, their state of being seeds. Its awakening

original: ālambane saṃmukhībhāvaḥ / prasaṃkhyānavato dagdhakleśabījasya saṃmukhībhūte 'py ālambane nāsau punar asti /
analyzed: ālambane saṃmukhībhāvaḥ prasaṃkhyānavataḥ dagdha kleśa bījasya saṃmukhībhūte pi ālambane na asau punar asti
translated: is the manifestation of the object. For one who has thoroughly discriminated, whose seeds of defilements have been burned, even when the object is present, it does not exist again.

original: dagdhabījasya kutaḥ praroha iti / ataḥ kṣīṇakleśaḥ kuśalaś caramadeha ity ucyate /
analyzed: dagdha bījasya kutas prarohaḥ iti atas kṣīṇa kleśaḥ kuśalaḥ carama dehaḥ iti ucyate
translated: How can there be growth for one whose seeds have been burned? Therefore, one whose defilements have been destroyed and who is virtuous is called one in the final body.

original: tatraiva sā dagdhabījabhāvā pañcamī kleśāvasthā nānyatreti / satāṃ kleśānāṃ tadā bījasāmarthyaṃ
analyzed: tatra eva sā dagdha bīja bhāvā pañcamī kleśa avasthā nā anyatra iti satām kleśānām tadā bīja sāmarthyam
translated: In that very state, that fifth state of defilements, whose seeds have been burned, not elsewhere. Then the potentiality of the existing defilements

original: dagdham iti viṣayasya saṃmukhībhāve 'pi sati na bhavaty eṣāṃ prabodha ity uktā prasuptir
analyzed: dagdham iti viṣayasya saṃmukhībhāve sati na bhavati eṣām prabodhaḥ iti uktā prasuptiḥ
translated: is burned. Even when the object is present, their awakening does not occur. Thus dormancy is stated.

original: dagdhabījānām aprarohaś ca /
analyzed: dagdha bījānām aprarohaḥ ca
translated: The non-growth of those whose seeds have been burned.

original: tanutvam ucyate pratipakṣabhāvanopahatāḥ kleśās tanavo bhavanti / tathā vicchidya vicchidya tena tenātmanā punaḥ punaḥ samudācarantīti vicchinnāḥ /
analyzed: tanu tvam ucyate pratipakṣa bhāvanā upahatāḥ kleśāḥ tanavaḥ bhavanti tathā vicchidya vicchidya tena tena ātmanā punar punar samudācaranti iti vicchinnāḥ
translated: It is said that the defilements become weak when they are afflicted by the cultivation of their antidotes. Similarly, they operate again and again in various ways, being interrupted.

original: rāgakāle krodhasyādarśanāt / na hi rāgakāle krodhaḥ samudācarati / rāgaś ca kvacid dṛśyamāno na viṣayāntare nāsti / naikasyāṃ striyāṃ caitro rakta
analyzed: rāga kāle krodhasya adarśanāt na hi rāga kāle krodhaḥ samudācarati rāgaḥ ca kvacid dṛśyamānaḥ na viṣaya antare na asti na ekasyām striyām caitraḥ
translated: Because anger is not seen at the time of passion. For anger does not operate at the time of passion. And passion, being seen in one place, does not exist in another object. Caitra is not attached to one woman.

original: ity anyāsu strīṣu viraktaḥ /
analyzed: iti anyāsu strīṣu viraktaḥ
translated: He is not detached from other women.

original: kiṃtu tatra rāgo labdhavṛttir anyatra tu bhaviṣyadvṛttir iti / sa hi tadā prasuptatanuvicchinno bhavati /
analyzed: kiṃtu tatra rāgaḥ labdha vṛttiḥ anyatra tu bhaviṣyat vṛttiḥ iti sa hi tadā prasupta tanu vicchinnaḥ bhavati
translated: But at that time, passion has obtained its function there, but it will have its function in another place. For it is then dormant, weak, and interrupted.

original: viṣaye yo labdhavṛttiḥ sa udāraḥ / sarva evaite kleśaviṣayatvaṃ nātikrāmanti / kas tarhi vicchinnaḥ prasuptas tanur udāro vā kleśa iti /
analyzed: viṣaye yaḥ labdha vṛttiḥ saḥ udāraḥ sarve eva ete kleśa viṣaya tvam na atikrāmanti kaḥ tarhi vicchinnaḥ prasuptaḥ tanuḥ udāraḥ vā kleśaḥ iti
translated: That which has obtained its function in an object is extensive. All of these do not go beyond being the objects of defilements. Then which defilement is interrupted, dormant, weak, or extensive?

original: ucyate satyam evaitat /
analyzed: ucyate satyam eva etat
translated: It is said that this is indeed true.

original: kiṃtu viśiṣṭānām evaiteṣāṃ vicchinnāditvam / yathaiva pratipakṣabhāvanāto nivṛttas tathaiva svavyañjakāñjanenābhivyakta iti / sarva evāmī kleśā
analyzed: kiṃtu viśiṣṭānām eva eteṣām vicchinna ādi tvam yathā eva pratipakṣa bhāvanātaḥ nivṛttaḥ tathā eva sva vyañjaka añjanena abhivyaktaḥ iti sarve eva amī kleśāḥ
translated: However, only the distinguished ones have a discontinuous etc. nature, just as one who has turned away from the cultivation of antidotes is manifested by the application of their manifesting factors. All these afflictions

original: avidyābhedāḥ / kasmāt /🔽sarveṣv avidyaivābhiplavate / yad avidyayā vastv ākāryate tad evānuśerate kleśā viparyāsapratyayakāla upalabhyante kṣīyamāṇāṃ cāvidyām anu kṣīyanta
analyzed: avidyā bhedāḥ kasmāt  sarveṣu avidyā eva abhiplavate yat avidyayā vastu ākāryate tat eva anuśerate kleśāḥ viparyāsa pratyaya kāle upalabhyante kṣīyamāṇām ca avidyām anu kṣīyanta
translated: are varieties of ignorance. Why is that?

original: iti / /
analyzed: iti
translated: Because ignorance pervades all of them. Whatever is grasped as an object by ignorance, those very afflictions are produced, and are perceived at the time of the conditions of inversion, and when ignorance is being destroyed, they are destroyed along with it.

original: tatrāvidyāsvarūpam ucyate
analyzed: tatra avidyā svarūpam ucyate
translated: The nature of ignorance is stated there:

original: anityāśuciduḥkhānātmasu nityaśucisukhātmakhyātir avidyā // / //
analyzed: anitya aśuci duḥkha anātmasu nitya śuci sukha ātma khyātiḥ avidyā
translated: Ignorance is the appearance of the impermanent, impure, suffering, and non-self as permanent, pure, blissful, and self.

original: anitye kārye nityakhyātiḥ / tadyathā dhruvā pṛthivī /
analyzed: anitye kārye nitya khyātiḥ tat yathā dhruvā pṛthivī
translated: The appearance of the impermanent, which is a product, as permanent, like the earth is stable.

original: dhruvā sacandratārakā dyauḥ /
analyzed: dhruvā sa candra tārakā dyauḥ
translated: The sky with the moon and stars is stable.

original: amṛtā divaukasa iti / tathāśucau paramabībhatse kāye /
analyzed: amṛtāḥ divaukasaḥ iti tathā aśucau parama bībhatse kāye
translated: The gods are immortal. Similarly, in the body, which is extremely impure and disgusting,

original: sthānād bījād upaṣṭambhān niḥsyandān nidhanād api /
analyzed: sthānāt bījāt upaṣṭambhāt niḥsyandāt nidhanāt api
translated: from the place, from the seed, from the support, from the outflow, and from the destruction,

original: kāyam ādheyaśaucatvāt paṇḍitā hy aśuciṃ viduḥ //
analyzed: kāyam ādheya śauca tvāt paṇḍitāḥ hi aśucim viduḥ
translated: the wise know the body to be impure because it is something that can be made pure.

original: iti aśucau śucikhyātir dṛśyate / naveva śaśāṅkalekhā kamanīyeyaṃ kanyā madhvamṛtāvayavanirmiteva candraṃ bhittvā niḥsṛteva jñāyate /
analyzed: iti aśucau śuci khyātiḥ dṛśyate navā iva śaśāṅka lekhā kamanīyā iyam kanyā madhu amṛta avayava nirmitā iva candram bhittvā niḥsṛtā iva jñāyate
translated: Thus, purity is seen in impurity. This girl is indeed very lovely, like the digit of the new moon, as if created from the essence of sweet nectar, as if emerging by splitting the moon.

original: nīlotpalapatrāyatākṣī hāvagarbhābhyāṃ locanābhyāṃ jīvalokam āśvāsayantīveti kasya
analyzed: nīlotpala patra āyata akṣī hāva garbhābhyām locanābhyām jīva lokam āśvāsayantī iva iti kasya
translated: With eyes elongated like lotus petals, as if comforting the world of living beings with her affectionate glances. To whom

original: kenābhisaṃbandhaḥ / bhavati caivam aśucau śuciviparyāsapratyaya iti / etenāpuṇye puṇyapratyayas
analyzed: kena abhisaṃbandhaḥ bhavati ca evam aśucau śuci viparyāsa pratyayaḥ iti etena apuṇye puṇya pratyayaḥ
translated: is this related? And thus, the condition of purity in impurity arises. By this, the condition of merit in demerit is explained.

original: tathaivānarthe cārthapratyayo vyākhyātaḥ /🔽tathā duḥkhe sukhakhyātiṃ vakṣyati pariṇāmatāpasaṃskāraduḥkhair guṇavṛttivirodhāc
analyzed: tathā eva anarthe ca artha pratyayaḥ vyākhyātaḥ  tathā duḥkhe sukha khyātim vakṣyati pariṇāma tāpa saṃskāra duḥkhaiḥ guṇa vṛtti virodhāt
translated: Similarly, the condition of benefit in harm is explained.🔽Similarly, he will say about the appearance of happiness in suffering: For the discerning one, everything is suffering due to the suffering of change, torment, and formation, and due to the contradiction of the function of the qualities.

original: ca duḥkham eva sarvaṃ vivekinaḥ iti / tatra sukhakhyātir avidyā / tathānātmany ātmakhyātir
analyzed: ca duḥkham eva sarvam vivekinaḥ iti tatra sukha khyātiḥ avidyā tathā anātmani ātma khyātiḥ
translated: There, the appearance of happiness is ignorance. Similarly, the appearance of the self in the non-self

original: bāhyopakaraṇeṣu cetanācetaneṣu bhogādhiṣṭhāne vā śarīre puruṣopakaraṇe vā manasy
analyzed: bāhya upakaraṇeṣu cetana acetaneṣu bhoga adhiṣṭhāne vā śarīre puruṣa upakaraṇe vā manasi
translated: in external instruments, whether sentient or insentient, or in the body which is the basis of enjoyment, or in the mind which is the instrument of the self,

original: anātmany ātmakhyātir iti / tathaitad atroktam vyaktam avyaktaṃ vā sattvam ātmatvenābhipratītya
analyzed: anātmani ātma khyātiḥ iti tathā etat atra uktam vyaktam avyaktam vā sattvam ātma tvena abhipratītya
translated: is the appearance of the self in the non-self. Thus, this is said here: Perceiving the manifest or unmanifest nature as the self,

original: tasya saṃpadam anu nandaty ātmasaṃpadaṃ manvānas tasya vyāpadam anu śocaty ātmavyāpadaṃ
analyzed: tasya saṃpadam anu nandati ātma saṃpadam manvānaḥ tasya vyāpadam anu śocati ātma vyāpadam
translated: Rejoicing in his prosperity, considering it his own prosperity, grieving over his adversity, considering it his own adversity,

original: manvānaḥ sa sarvo 'pratibuddhaḥ iti / eṣā catuṣpadā bhavaty avidyā mūlam asya kleśasaṃtānasya
analyzed: manvānaḥ sa sarvaḥ pratibuddhaḥ iti eṣā catuṣpadā bhavati avidyā mūlam asya kleśa saṃtānasya
translated: all this is ignorance. And this ignorance has four aspects, it is the root of this continuum of afflictions

original: karmāśayasya ca savipākasyeti /🔽tasyāś cāmitrāgoṣpadavadvastusatattvaṃ vijñeyam / yathā nāmitro mitrābhāvo na mitramātraṃ
analyzed: karma āśayasya ca sa vipākasya iti  tasyāḥ ca amitra goṣpada vat vastu sa tattvam vijñeyam yathā na amitraḥ mitra abhāvaḥ na mitra mātram
translated: and of the store of karma with its results.🔽And the true nature of the reality of ignorance should be known to be like a non-friend or a cow's footprint. Just as a non-friend is not the mere absence of a friend,

original: kiṃtu tadviruddhaḥ sapatnaḥ / yathā vāgoṣpadaṃ na goṣpadābhāvo na goṣpadamātraṃ kiṃtu
analyzed: kiṃtu tad viruddhaḥ sapatnaḥ yathā vā a goṣpadam na goṣpada abhāvaḥ na goṣpada mātram kiṃtu
translated: but rather its opposite, an enemy. Just as a cow's footprint is not the mere absence of a footprint, but rather

original: deśa eva tābhyām anyad vastvantaram / evam avidyā na pramāṇaṃ na pramāṇābhāvaḥ kiṃtu
analyzed: deśaḥ eva tābhyām anyat vastu antaram evam avidyā na pramāṇam na pramāṇa abhāvaḥ kiṃtu
translated: a different thing altogether in that place, in the same way, ignorance is not a valid cognition, nor the mere absence of a valid cognition, but rather

original: vidyāviparītaṃ jñānāntaram avidyeti / /🔽dṛgdarśanaśaktyor ekātmatevāsmitā // / //
analyzed: vidyā viparītam jñāna antaram avidyā iti  dṛś darśana śaktyoḥ eka ātma tā iva asmitā
translated: a different kind of knowledge that is contrary to knowledge, it is ignorance.🔽The identification of the seer and the seen as being the same is the affliction of I-am-ness.

original: puruṣo dṛkśaktir buddhir darśanaśaktir ity etayor ekasvarūpāpattir ivāsmitā kleśa
analyzed: puruṣaḥ dṛś śaktiḥ buddhiḥ darśana śaktiḥ iti etayoḥ eka svarūpa āpattiḥ iva asmitā kleśa
translated: The purusha is the power of seeing, the buddhi is the power of the seen. The identification of these two as if they were of the same nature is the affliction of I-am-ness.

original: ucyate / bhoktṛbhogyaśaktyor atyantavibhaktayor atyantāsaṃkīrṇayor avibhāgaprāptāv
analyzed: ucyate bhoktṛ bhogya śaktyoḥ atyanta vibhaktayoḥ atyanta asaṃkīrṇayoḥ avibhāga prāptau
translated: It is said: When the power of the enjoyer and the power of the object become completely separated, completely unmixed, and attain a state of non-separation,

original: iva satyāṃ bhogaḥ kalpate / svarūpapratilambhe tu tayoḥ kaivalyam eva bhavati kuto
analyzed: iva satyām bhogaḥ kalpate sva rūpa pratilambhe tu tayoḥ kaivalyam eva bhavati kutas
translated: enjoyment becomes possible. But when they attain their own nature, there is only liberation for them. How can there be

original: bhoga iti / tathā coktam buddhitaḥ paraṃ puruṣam ākāraśīlavidyādibhir vibhaktam
analyzed: bhogaḥ iti tathā ca uktam buddhitaḥ param puruṣam ākāra śīla vidyā ādibhiḥ vibhaktam
translated: enjoyment? And it is said: Not seeing the Purusha beyond the intellect, distinguished by form, character, knowledge, etc.,

original: apaśyan kuryāt tatrātmabuddhiṃ mohena iti / /
analyzed: a paśyan kuryāt tatra ātma buddhim mohena iti
translated: one may mistakenly identify it as the self through delusion.

original: sukhānuśayī rāgaḥ // / //
analyzed: sukha anuśayī rāgaḥ
translated: Attachment is the tendency to pleasure.

original: sukhābhijñasya sukhānusmṛtipūrvaḥ sukhe tatsādhane vā yo gardhas tṛṣṇā lobhaḥ sa rāga iti / /
analyzed: sukha abhijñasya sukha anusmṛti pūrvaḥ sukhe tad sādhane vā yaḥ gardhaḥ tṛṣṇā lobhaḥ sa rāgaḥ iti
translated: For one who knows pleasure, attachment is the longing, craving, greed that precedes the recollection of pleasure, or for the means to pleasure. That is attachment.

original: duḥkhānuśayī dveṣaḥ // / //
analyzed: duḥkha anuśayī dveṣaḥ
translated: Aversion is the tendency to pain.

original: duḥkhābhijñasya duḥkhānusmṛtipūrvo duḥkhe tatsādhane vā yaḥ pratigho manyur jighāṃsā krodhaḥ sa dveṣaḥ / /
analyzed: duḥkha abhijñasya duḥkha anusmṛti pūrvaḥ duḥkhe tad sādhane vā yaḥ pratighaḥ manyuḥ jighāṃsā krodhaḥ sa dveṣaḥ
translated: For one who knows pain, aversion is the resistance, resentment, desire to harm, anger that precedes pain or the means to pain. That is aversion.

original: svarasavāhī viduṣo 'pi tathā rūḍho 'bhiniveśaḥ // / //
analyzed: sva rasa vāhī tathā rūḍhaḥ bhiniveśaḥ
translated: Habituation is the deep-rooted attachment that flows naturally, even for the wise.

original: sarvasya prāṇina iyam ātmāśīr nityā bhavati mā na bhūvaṃ bhūyāsam iti / na cānanubhūtamaraṇadharmakasyaiṣā
analyzed: sarvasya prāṇinaḥ iyam ātma āśīḥ nityā bhavati mā na bhūvam bhūyāsam iti na ca ananubhūta maraṇa dharmakasya eṣā
translated: This is the eternal blessing of the self for all living beings: May I not be; may I be; may I become. And this is not for one who has not experienced death.

original: bhavaty ātmāśīḥ / etayā ca pūrvajanmānubhavaḥ pratīyate / sa cāyam abhiniveśaḥ kleśaḥ
analyzed: bhavati ātma āśīḥ etayā ca pūrva janma anubhavaḥ pratīyate sa ca ayam abhiniveśaḥ kleśaḥ
translated: The soul-wish arises. And this [soul-wish] is understood to be the experience of past lives. And this attachment is an affliction.

original: svarasavāhī kṛmer api jātamātrasya pratyakṣānumānāgamair asaṃbhāvito maraṇatrāsa
analyzed: sva rasa vāhī kṛmeḥ api jāta mātrasya pratyakṣa anumāna āgamaiḥ asaṃbhāvitaḥ maraṇa trāsa
translated: It flows naturally, even in a worm as soon as it is born, and is not imagined by perception, inference, or scripture. The fear of death

original: ucchedadṛṣṭyātmakaḥ pūrvajanmānubhūtaṃ maraṇaduḥkham anumāpayati /
analyzed: uccheda dṛṣṭi ātmakaḥ pūrva janma anubhūtam maraṇa duḥkham anumāpayati
translated: consisting of the view of annihilation implies the suffering of death experienced in past lives.

original: yathā cāyam atyantamūḍheṣu dṛśyate kleśas tathā viduṣo 'pi vijñātapūrvāparāntasya rūḍhaḥ / kasmāt samānā hi tayoḥ kuśalākuśalayor maraṇaduḥkhānubhavād
analyzed: yathā ca ayam atyanta mūḍheṣu dṛśyate kleśaḥ tathā viduṣaḥ pi vijñāta pūrva apara antasya rūḍhaḥ kasmāt samānāḥ hi tayoḥ kuśala akuśalayoḥ maraṇa duḥkha anubhavāt  /
translated: And just as this affliction is seen even in the extremely deluded, so it is firmly established in the wise who know the past and future. Why? Because the suffering of death is the same for both the virtuous and the non-virtuous.

original: iyaṃ vāsaneti / /
analyzed: iyam vāsanā iti
translated: Therefore, this is the latent tendency.

original: te pratiprasavaheyāḥ sūkṣmāḥ // / //
analyzed: te pratiprasava heyāḥ sūkṣmāḥ
translated: They are to be abandoned by the antidote of counteraction. They are subtle.

original: te pañca kleśā dagdhabījakalpā yoginaś caritādhikāre cetasi pralīne saha tenaivāstaṃ gacchanti / /
analyzed: te pañca kleśāḥ dagdha bīja kalpāḥ yoginaḥ carita adhikāre cetasi pralīne saha tena eva astam gacchanti
translated: Those five afflictions, like burnt seeds, when the yogi's mind has dissolved in the domain of practice, go to rest along with that.

original: sthitānāṃ tu bījabhāvopagatānām
analyzed: sthitānām tu bīja bhāva upagatānām
translated: But for those who remain, having attained the state of seeds,

original: dhyānaheyās tadvṛttayaḥ // / //
analyzed: dhyāna heyāḥ tad vṛttayaḥ
translated: Their manifestations are to be abandoned by meditation.

original: kleśānāṃ yā vṛttayaḥ sthūlās tāḥ kriyāyogena tanūkṛtāḥ satyaḥ prasaṃkhyānena dhyānena
analyzed: kleśānām yāḥ vṛttayaḥ sthūlāḥ tāḥ kriyā yogena tanūkṛtāḥ satyaḥ prasaṃkhyānena dhyānena
translated: The gross manifestations of the afflictions, when made subtle by the yoga of action, are abandoned by the meditation of discernment.

original: hātavyā yāvat sūkṣmīkṛtā yāvad dagdhabījakalpā iti / yathā vastrāṇāṃ sthūlo malaḥ🔽pūrvaṃ nirdhūyate paścāt sūkṣmo yatnenopāyena cāpanīyate tathā svalpapratipakṣāḥ
analyzed: hātavyāḥ yāvat sūkṣmīkṛtāḥ yāvat dagdha bīja kalpāḥ iti yathā vastrāṇām sthūlaḥ malaḥ  pūrvam nirdhūyate paścāt sūkṣmaḥ yatnena upāyena ca apanīyate tathā su alpa pratipakṣāḥ
translated: As long as they are to be abandoned, as long as they are made subtle, as long as they are like seeds burned, just as the coarse dirt of clothes🔽is shaken off first, and then the subtle dirt is removed with effort and means, so the coarse manifestations of the afflictions

original: sthūlā vṛttayaḥ kleśānāṃ /
analyzed: sthūlāḥ vṛttayaḥ kleśānām
translated: are with little counteraction,

original: sūkṣmās tu mahāpratipakṣā iti / /🔽kleśamūlaḥ karmāśayo dṛṣṭādṛṣṭajanmavedanīyaḥ // / //
analyzed: sūkṣmāḥ tu mahā pratipakṣāḥ iti  kleśa mūlaḥ karma āśayaḥ dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyaḥ
translated: but the subtle ones are with great counteraction.🔽The accumulation of karma rooted in afflictions, to be experienced in this life and in future lives, is...

original: tatra puṇyāpuṇyakarmāśayaḥ kāmalobhamohakrodhabhavaḥ / sa dṛṣṭajanmavedanīyaś cādṛṣṭajanmavedanīyaś
analyzed: tatra puṇya apuṇya karma āśayaḥ kāma lobha moha krodha bhavaḥ sa dṛṣṭa janma vedanīyaḥ ca adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyaḥ
translated: Therein, the accumulation of meritorious and non-meritorious karma arises from desire, greed, delusion, and anger. It is to be experienced in this life and in future lives,

original: ca / tatra tīvrasaṃvegena mantratapaḥsamādhibhir nirvartita īśvaradevatāmaharṣimahānubhāvānām
analyzed: ca tatra tīvra saṃvegena mantra tapaḥ samādhibhiḥ nirvartitaḥ īśvara devatā mahā ṛṣi mahā anubhāvānām
translated: and in that, the one that is accomplished by one with intense feeling, through mantras, austerities, and meditation, or by propitiating powerful gods, great sages, and those of great power,

original: ārādhanād vā yaḥ pariniṣpannaḥ sa sadyaḥ paripacyate puṇyakarmāśaya iti / tathā tīvrakleśena
analyzed: ārādhanāt vā yaḥ pariniṣpannaḥ sa sadyas paripacyate puṇya karma āśaye iti tathā tīvra kleśena
translated: that fully accomplished one ripens immediately. That is the accumulation of meritorious karma. Similarly, one with intense afflictions,

original: bhītavyādhitakṛpaṇeṣu viśvāsopagateṣu vā mahānubhāveṣu vā tapasviṣu kṛtaḥ punaḥ punar
analyzed: bhīta vyādhita kṛpaṇeṣu viśvāsa upagateṣu vā mahā anubhāveṣu vā tapasviṣu kṛtaḥ punar punar
translated: or one who has repeatedly done it to the fearful, the sick, the poor, or to those who have come for refuge, or to those of great power who are ascetics,

original: apakāraḥ sa cāpi pāpakarmāśayaḥ sadya eva paripacyate / yathā nandīśvaraḥ kumāro manuṣyapariṇāmaṃ
analyzed: apakāraḥ sa ca api pāpa karma āśayaḥ sadyas eva paripacyate yathā nandīśvaraḥ kumāraḥ manuṣya pariṇāmam
translated: And that evil intention to harm ripens immediately, just as the young god Nandīśvara,

original: hitvā devatvena pariṇataḥ / tathā nahuṣo 'pi devānām indraḥ svakaṃ pariṇāmaṃ hitvā🔽tiryaktvena pariṇata iti / tatra nārakāṇāṃ nāsti dṛṣṭajanmavedanīyaḥ karmāśayaḥ / kṣīṇakleśānām
analyzed: hitvā deva tvena pariṇataḥ tathā nahuṣaḥ pi devānām indraḥ svakam pariṇāmam hitvā  tiryaktvena pariṇataḥ iti tatra nārakāṇām na asti dṛṣṭa janma vedanīyaḥ karma āśayaḥ kṣīṇa kleśānām
translated: having abandoned the human transformation, was transformed into a god. Similarly, Nahuṣa, the lord of the gods, having abandoned his own transformation,🔽was transformed into an animal. There, for the hell beings, there is no intention to experience the ripening of karma in this life.

original: api nāsty adṛṣṭajanmavedanīyaḥ karmāśaya iti / /
analyzed: api na asti adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyaḥ karma āśayaḥ iti
translated: Even for those whose defilements are exhausted, there is no intention to experience the ripening of karma in a future life.

original: sati mūle tadvipāko jātyāyurbhogāḥ // / //🔽satsu kleśeṣu karmāśayo vipākārambhī bhavati nocchinnakleśamūlaḥ / yathā tuṣāvanaddhāḥ śālitaṇḍulā adagdhabījabhāvāḥ prarohasamarthā bhavanti /
analyzed: sati mūle tad vipākaḥ jāti āyuḥ bhogāḥ  satsu kleśeṣu karma āśayaḥ vipāka ārambhī bhavati na ucchinna kleśa mūlaḥ yathā tuṣa avanaddhāḥ śāli taṇḍulāḥ adagdha bīja bhāvāḥ praroha samarthāḥ bhavanti
translated: When there is a root, its ripening is birth, life, and enjoyment.🔽When there are defilements, the intention of karma becomes capable of ripening. Not when the root of defilements is cut off. Just as rice grains enclosed in husks, with undestroyed seed nature, are capable of sprouting,

original: nāpanītatuṣā dagdhabījabhāvā vā tathā kleśāvanaddhaḥ karmāśayo vipākaprarohī bhavati /
analyzed: na apanīta tuṣāḥ dagdha bīja bhāvāḥ vā tathā kleśa avanaddhaḥ karma āśayaḥ vipāka prarohī bhavati
translated: so the intention of karma enclosed in defilements is capable of sprouting as ripening.

original: nāpanītakleśo na prasaṃkhyānadagdhakleśabījabhāvo veti / sa ca vipākas trividho jātir āyur bhoga iti /
analyzed: na apanīta kleśaḥ na prasaṃkhyāna dagdha kleśa bīja bhāvaḥ vā iti sa ca vipākaḥ trividhaḥ jātiḥ āyuḥ bhogaḥ iti
translated: Not when the defilements are removed, or when the seed nature of the defilements is burned by discernment. And that ripening is threefold: birth, life, and enjoyment.

original: tatredaṃ vicāryate kim ekaṃ karmaikasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam athaikaṃ karmānekaṃ🔽janmākṣipatīti / dvitīyā vicāraṇā kim anekaṃ karmānekaṃ janma nirvartayati athānekaṃ
analyzed: tatra idam vicāryate kim ekam karma ekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam atha ekam karma anekam  janma ākṣipati iti dvitīyā vicāraṇā kim anekam karma anekam janma nirvartayati atha anekam
translated: Regarding this, this is to be considered: Is one karma the cause of one birth, or does one karma project many

original: karmaikaṃ janma nirvartayatīti / na tāvad ekaṃ karmaikasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam / kasmāt /
analyzed: karma ekam janma nirvartayati iti na tāvat ekam karma ekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam kasmāt
translated: births? The second consideration is: Do many karmas produce many births, or do many karmas produce one birth? First, one karma is not the cause of one birth. Why?

original: anādikālapracitasyāsaṃkhyeyasyāvaśiṣṭasya karmaṇaḥ sāṃpratikasya ca phalakramāniyamād anāśvāso lokasya prasaktaḥ /
analyzed: anādi kāla pracitasya asaṃkhyeyasya avaśiṣṭasya karmaṇaḥ sāṃpratikasya ca phala krama aniyamāt anāśvāsaḥ lokasya prasaktaḥ
translated: Because the order of the results of karma accumulated since beginningless time, which is innumerable, and of present karma, is uncertain, it follows that people have no confidence [in the law of karma].

original: sa cāniṣṭa iti / na caikaṃ karmānekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam / kasmāt /
analyzed: sa ca aniṣṭaḥ iti na ca ekam karma anekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam kasmāt
translated: And that is undesirable. And one karma is not the cause of many births. Why?

original: anekeṣu karmasu ekaikam eva karmānekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam ity avaśiṣṭasya vipākakālābhāvaḥ prasaktaḥ /
analyzed: anekeṣu karmasu ekaikam eva karma anekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam iti avaśiṣṭasya vipāka kāla abhāvaḥ prasaktaḥ
translated: Because in many karmas, each karma is the cause of one birth, it follows that there is no time for the ripening of the rest.

original: sa cāpy aniṣṭa iti / na cānekaṃ karmānekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam / kasmāt /
analyzed: sa ca api aniṣṭaḥ iti na ca anekam karma anekasya janmanaḥ kāraṇam kasmāt
translated: And that is also undesirable. And many karmas are not the cause of one birth. Why?

original: tad anekaṃ janma yugapan na saṃbhavatīti krameṇaiva vācyam / tathā ca pūrvadoṣānuṣaṅgaḥ /
analyzed: tat anekam janma yugapad na saṃbhavati iti krameṇa eva vācyam tathā ca pūrva doṣa anuṣaṅgaḥ
translated: Because many births cannot occur simultaneously, it must be said that [many karmas produce many births] only in sequence. And in that case, the previously mentioned fault continues.

original: tasmāj janmaprāyaṇāntare kṛtaḥ puṇyāpuṇyakarmāśayapracayo vicitraḥ pradhānopasarjanabhāvenāvasthitaḥ
analyzed: tasmāt janma prāyaṇa antare kṛtaḥ puṇya apuṇya karma āśaya pracayaḥ vicitraḥ pradhāna upasarjana bhāvena avasthitaḥ
translated: Therefore, the various accumulations of meritorious and non-meritorious karmic impressions made between birth and death exist in the form of principal and secondary [factors].

original: prāyaṇābhivyakta ekapraghaṭṭakena maraṇaṃ prasādhya saṃmūrchita ekam eva janma karoti /🔽tac ca janma tenaiva karmaṇā labdhāyuṣkaṃ bhavati / tasminn āyuṣi tenaiva karmaṇā
analyzed: prāyaṇa abhivyaktaḥ eka praghaṭṭakena maraṇam prasādhya saṃmūrchitaḥ ekam eva janma karoti  tat ca janma tena eva karmaṇā labdha āyuṣkam bhavati tasmin āyuṣi tena eva karmaṇā
translated: Manifested by death, they accomplish one birth through a single impetus.🔽And that birth has a lifespan obtained by that very karma. In that lifespan,

original: bhogaḥ saṃpadyata iti / asau karmāśayo janmāyurbhogahetutvāt trivipāko 'bhidhīyata
analyzed: bhogaḥ saṃpadyate iti asau karma āśayaḥ janma āyuḥ bhoga hetu tvāt tri vipākaḥ bhidhīyata
translated: enjoyment is accomplished by that very karma. Thus, that karmic impression is said to have three results because it is the cause of birth, lifespan, and enjoyment.

original: iti / ata ekabhavikaḥ karmāśaya ukta iti /
analyzed: iti atas eka bhavikaḥ karma āśayaḥ uktaḥ iti
translated: Thus, it is said that the karmic impression has a single existence.

original: dṛṣṭajanmavedanīyas tv ekavipākārambhī bhogahetutvād dvivipākārambhī vāyurbhogahetutvān
analyzed: dṛṣṭa janma vedanīyaḥ tu eka vipāka ārambhī bhoga hetu tvāt dvi vipāka ārambhī vāyuḥ bhoga hetu tvāt
translated: However, that which is to be experienced in this very life has one result, because it is the cause of enjoyment. Or it has two results, because it is the cause of lifespan and enjoyment.

original: nandīśvaravan nahuṣavad veti / kleśakarmavipākānubhavanirvartitābhis tu vāsanābhir
analyzed: nandīśvara vat nahuṣa vat vā iti kleśa karma vipāka anubhava nirvartitābhiḥ tu vāsanābhiḥ
translated: Like Nandiśvara or Nahuṣa. But by the impressions that are accomplished by the experience of afflictions, karma, and results,

original: anādikālasaṃmūrchitam idaṃ cittaṃ vicitrīkṛtam iva sarvato matsyajālaṃ granthibhir
analyzed: anādi kāla saṃmūrchitam idam cittam vicitrīkṛtam iva sarvatas matsya jālam granthibhiḥ
translated: this mind, which has been accumulated since beginningless time, is as if variegated in all ways like a fisherman's net with knots.

original: ivātatam ity etā anekabhavapūrvikā vāsanāḥ / yas tv ayaṃ karmāśaya eṣa evaikabhavika
analyzed: iva ātatam iti etāḥ aneka bhava pūrvikāḥ vāsanāḥ yaḥ tu ayam karma āśayaḥ eṣaḥ eva aika bhavika
translated: These are the latent impressions that have existed since beginningless time. But this karmic residuum that is said to last only one lifetime is

original: ukta iti / ye saṃskārāḥ smṛtihetavas tā vāsanās tāś cānādikālīnā iti /🔽yas tv asāv ekabhavikaḥ karmāśayaḥ sa niyatavipākaś cāniyatavipākaś ca / tatra dṛṣṭajanmavedanīyasya
analyzed: uktaḥ iti ye saṃskārāḥ smṛti hetavaḥ tāḥ vāsanāḥ tāḥ ca anādi kālīnāḥ iti  yaḥ tu asau eka bhavikaḥ karma āśayaḥ sa niyata vipākaḥ ca aniyata vipākaḥ ca tatra dṛṣṭa janma vedanīyasya
translated: said to be of two kinds. Those latent impressions that are the causes of memory exist since beginningless time.

original: niyatavipākasyaivāyaṃ niyamo na tv adṛṣṭajanmavedanīyasyāniyatavipākasya kasmāt /
analyzed: niyata vipākasya eva ayam niyamaḥ na tu adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyasya aniyata vipākasya kasmāt
translated: But that karmic residuum that lasts only one lifetime is of two kinds: that which has fixed ripening and that which has unfixed ripening. Among them, this rule applies only to that which has fixed ripening and is to be experienced in the present lifetime, not to that which has unfixed ripening and is to be experienced in a future lifetime. Why is that?

original: yo hy adṛṣṭajanmavedanīyo 'niyatavipākas tasya trayī gatiḥ kṛtasyāvipakvasya nāśaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ hi adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyaḥ niyata vipākaḥ tasya trayī gatiḥ kṛtasya avipakvasya nāśaḥ
translated: For that which is to be experienced in a future lifetime and has unfixed ripening, there are three possibilities: destruction of what has been done but not yet ripened,

original: pradhānakarmaṇy āvāpagamanaṃ vā /
analyzed: pradhāna karmaṇi āvāpa gamanam vā
translated: or merging into the principal karma,

original: niyatavipākapradhānakarmaṇābhibhūtasya vā ciram avasthānam iti /
analyzed: niyata vipāka pradhāna karmaṇā abhibhūtasya vā ciram avasthānam iti
translated: or remaining for a long time overwhelmed by the principal karma with fixed ripening.

original: tatra kṛtasyāvipakvasya nāśo yathā śuklakarmodayād ihaiva nāśaḥ kṛṣṇasya / yatredam
analyzed: tatra kṛtasya avipakvasya nāśaḥ yathā śukla karma udayāt iha eva nāśaḥ kṛṣṇasya yatra idam
translated: Among them, the destruction of what has been done but not yet ripened is like the destruction of the black [karma] right here [in this life] by the arising of the white [karma]. Where this is said:

original: uktam dve dve ha vai karmaṇī veditavye pāpakasyaiko rāśiḥ puṇyakṛto 'pahanti
analyzed: uktam dve dve ha vai karmaṇī veditavye pāpakasya ekaḥ rāśiḥ puṇya kṛtaḥ u pahanti
translated: Two kinds of karma should be known, two kinds of black karma are destroyed by the meritorious one.

original: tad icchasva karmāṇi sukṛtāni kartum ihaiva te karma kavayo vedayante /
analyzed: tat icchasva karmāṇi su kṛtāni kartum iha eva te karma kavayaḥ vedayante
translated: Therefore, wish to perform good actions here itself. The wise declare that actions are performed here.

original: pradhānakarmaṇy āvāpagamanam / yatredam uktaṃ syāt svalpaḥ saṃkaraḥ saparihāraḥ sapratyavamarṣaḥ kuśalasya nāpakarṣāyālam / kasmāt /
analyzed: pradhāna karmaṇi āvāpa gamanam yatra idam uktam syāt su alpaḥ saṃkaraḥ sa parihāraḥ sa pratyavamarṣaḥ kuśalasya na apakarṣāya alam kasmāt
translated: The going to add to the principal action. Where this is said: 'The small mixture is avoidable, with forbearance, not enough to diminish the good. Why?

original: kuśalaṃ hi me bahv anyad asti yatrāyam āvāpaṃ gataḥ svarge 'py apakarṣam alpaṃ kariṣyati iti /
analyzed: kuśalam hi me bahu anyat asti yatra ayam āvāpam gataḥ svarge pi apakarṣam alpam kariṣyati iti
translated: Because I have much other good, where this going to add will make only a small diminution in heaven.'

original: niyatavipākapradhānakarmaṇābhibhūtasya vā ciram avasthānam / katham iti /
analyzed: niyata vipāka pradhāna karmaṇā abhibhūtasya vā ciram avasthānam katham iti
translated: Or, for one overwhelmed by a principal action with fixed result, there is a long duration. How?

original: adṛṣṭajanmavedanīyasyaiva niyatavipākasya karmaṇaḥ samānaṃ maraṇam abhivyaktikāraṇam
analyzed: adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyasya eva niyata vipākasya karmaṇaḥ samānam maraṇam abhivyakti kāraṇam
translated: The cause of manifestation is the same death for only that action with fixed result to be experienced in a future birth that is not seen.

original: uktam / na tv adṛṣṭajanmavedanīyasyāniyatavipākasya / yat tv adṛṣṭajanmavedanīyaṃ karmāniyatavipākaṃ
analyzed: uktam na tu adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyasya aniyata vipākasya yat tu adṛṣṭa janma vedanīyam karma aniyata vipākam
translated: It is said, but not for that with undetermined result to be experienced in a future birth that is not seen. But that action with undetermined result to be experienced in a future birth that is not seen

original: tan naśyed āvāpaṃ vā gacched abhibhūtaṃ vā ciram apy upāsīta /
analyzed: tat naśyet āvāpam vā gacchet abhibhūtam vā ciram api upāsīta
translated: either perishes, or goes to add, or waits for a long time, being overwhelmed.

original: yāvat samānaṃ karmābhivyañjakaṃ nimittam asya na vipākābhimukhaṃ karotīti / tadvipākasyaiva
analyzed: yāvat samānam karma abhivyañjakam nimittam asya na vipāka abhimukham karoti iti tad vipākasya eva
translated: As long as the same manifest cause does not turn it towards its fruition. For that fruition🔽

original: deśakālanimittānavadhāraṇād iyaṃ karmagatiś citrā durvijñānā ceti / na cotsargasyāpavādān
analyzed: deśa kāla nimittān avadhāraṇāt iyam karma gatiḥ citrā durvijñānā ca iti na ca utsargasya apavādān
translated: As long as the same manifest cause does not make it face its ripening. Because the place, time, and conditions of that ripening are not determined, this course of action is variegated and difficult to know. And because of the exception to the general rule,

original: nivṛttir ity ekabhavikaḥ karmāśayo 'nujñāyata iti / /
analyzed: nivṛttiḥ iti eka bhavikaḥ karma āśayaḥ nujñāyate iti
translated: the cessation [of action] does not occur. Thus, it is accepted that a single life-span of karmic tendencies [continues].

original: te hlādaparitāpaphalāḥ puṇyāpuṇyahetutvāt // / //
analyzed: te hlāda paritāpa phalāḥ puṇya apuṇya hetu tvāt
translated: They have the fruits of pleasure and pain, because they are the causes of merit and demerit.

original: te janmāyurbhogāḥ puṇyahetukāḥ sukhaphalā apuṇyahetukā duḥkhaphalā iti / yathā cedaṃ duḥkhaṃ pratikūlātmakam evaṃ viṣayasukhakāle 'pi duḥkham
analyzed: te janma āyuḥ bhogāḥ puṇya hetukāḥ sukha phalāḥ apuṇya hetukāḥ duḥkha phalāḥ iti yathā ca idam duḥkham pratikūla ātmakam evam viṣaya sukha kāle duḥkham
translated: Those births, life spans, and enjoyments are caused by merit and have the fruit of pleasure, and are caused by demerit and have the fruit of pain. And just as this pain has an unpleasant nature, so too does pain exist

original: asty eva pratikūlātmakaṃ yoginaḥ / /
analyzed: asti eva pratikūla ātmakam yoginaḥ
translated: for the yogi even at the time of sensual pleasure, having an unpleasant nature.

original: kathaṃ / tad upapādyate
analyzed: katham tat upapādyate
translated: How? That is being established.

original: pariṇāmatāpasaṃskāraduḥkhair guṇavṛttivirodhāc ca duḥkham eva sarvaṃ vivekinaḥ // / //
analyzed: pariṇāma tāpa saṃskāra duḥkhaiḥ guṇa vṛtti virodhāt ca duḥkham eva sarvam vivekinaḥ
translated: For the discerning one, everything is suffering because of the suffering of change, the suffering of pain, and the suffering of conditioned existence, and because of the contradiction of the function of the qualities.

original: sarvasyāyaṃ rāgānuviddhaś cetanācetanasādhanādhīnaḥ sukhānubhava iti tatrāsti rāgajaḥ
analyzed: sarvasya ayam rāga anuviddhaḥ cetana acetana sādhana adhīnaḥ sukha anubhavaḥ iti tatra asti rāga jaḥ
translated: This experience of pleasure, which is dependent on the means consisting of both conscious and unconscious [elements], is pervaded by attachment in all [cases]. Therefore, there is that born from attachment.

original: karmāśayaḥ / tathā ca dveṣṭi duḥkhasādhanāni muhyati ceti dveṣamohakṛto 'py asti karmāśayaḥ /
analyzed: karma āśayaḥ tathā ca dveṣṭi duḥkha sādhanāni muhyati ca iti asti karma āśayaḥ
translated: The latent impressions of action. And thus, one hates the means of suffering and is deluded, so the latent impressions of action also arise from hatred and delusion.

original: tathā coktam nānupahatya bhūtāny upabhogaḥ saṃbhavatīti hiṃsākṛto 'py asti śarīraḥ
analyzed: tathā ca uktam na an upahatya bhūtāni upabhogaḥ saṃbhavati iti hiṃsā kṛtaḥ api asti śarīraḥ
translated: And thus it is said: Enjoyment is not possible without harming beings, so the latent impressions of action also arise from violence.

original: karmāśayaḥ iti / viṣayasukhaṃ cāvidyety uktam /
analyzed: karma āśayaḥ iti viṣaya sukham ca avidyā iti uktam
translated: And it is said that the pleasure of objects is ignorance.

original: yā bhogeṣv indriyāṇāṃ tṛpter upaśāntis tat sukham / yā laulyād anupaśāntis tad duḥkham / na cendriyāṇāṃ bhogābhyāsena vaitṛṣṇyaṃ kartuṃ śakyam /🔽yato bhogābhyāsam anu vivardhante rāgāḥ kauśalāni cendriyāṇām iti / tasmād anupāyaḥ
analyzed: yā bhogeṣu indriyāṇām tṛpteḥ upaśāntiḥ tat sukham yā laulyāt anupaśāntiḥ tat duḥkham na ca indriyāṇām bhoga abhyāsena vaitṛṣṇyam kartum śakyam  yatas bhoga abhyāsam anu vivardhante rāgāḥ kauśalāni ca indriyāṇām iti tasmāt anupāyaḥ
translated: That pleasure which is the cessation of the senses' craving for enjoyments, that is happiness. That which is the non-cessation due to greed, that is suffering. And it is not possible to make the senses free from craving through practice of enjoyments.🔽Because the desires and skills of the senses increase in proportion to the practice of enjoyments. Therefore, the practice of enjoyments is not a means to happiness.

original: sukhasya bhogābhyāsa iti / sa khalv ayaṃ vṛścikaviṣabhīta ivāśīviṣeṇa daṣṭo yaḥ sukhārthī
analyzed: sukhasya bhoga abhyāsaḥ iti sa khalu ayam vṛścika viṣa bhītaḥ iva āśīviṣeṇa daṣṭaḥ yaḥ sukha arthī
translated: He who is afraid of the pain of a scorpion sting, as if bitten by a venomous snake, is one who seeks happiness.

original: viṣayānuvāsito mahati duḥkhapaṅke nimagna iti / eṣā pariṇāmaduḥkhatā nāma pratikūlā
analyzed: viṣaya anuvāsitaḥ mahati duḥkha paṅke nimagnaḥ iti eṣā pariṇāma duḥkha tā nāma pratikūlā
translated: He who is attached to objects is immersed in a great mire of suffering. This is called the suffering of change. It is unpleasant

original: sukhāvasthāyām api yoginam eva kliśnāti /
analyzed: sukha avasthāyām api yoginam eva kliśnāti
translated: and afflicts even the yogi in a state of happiness.

original: atha kā tāpaduḥkhatā /
analyzed: atha kā tāpa duḥkha tā
translated: Now, what is the suffering of pain?

original: sarvasya dveṣānuviddhaś cetanācetanasādhanādhīnas tāpānubhava iti tatrāsti dveṣajaḥ
analyzed: sarvasya dveṣa anuviddhaḥ cetana acetana sādhana adhīnaḥ tāpa anubhavaḥ iti tatra asti dveṣa jaḥ
translated: For all, the experience of pain is dependent on conscious and unconscious means, and is mixed with hatred. Therefore, there is a residuum of action born of hatred.

original: karmāśayaḥ / sukhasādhanāni ca prārthayamānaḥ kāyena vācā manasā ca parispandate tataḥ
analyzed: karma āśayaḥ sukha sādhanāni ca prārthayamānaḥ kāyena vācā manasā ca parispandate tatas
translated: Desiring the means to happiness, one moves the body, speech, and mind. From that,

original: param anugṛhṇāty upahanti ceti parānugrahapīḍābhyāṃ dharmādharmāv upacinoti / sa karmāśayo
analyzed: param anugṛhṇāti upahanti ca iti para anugraha pīḍābhyām dharma adharmau upacinoti sa karma āśayaḥ
translated: one benefits others and harms them. Thus, one accumulates virtue and vice through benefiting and harming others. That residuum of action

original: lobhān mohāc ca bhavatīty eṣā tāpaduḥkhatocyate / kā punaḥ saṃskāraduḥkhatā /
analyzed: lobhāt mohāt ca bhavati iti eṣā tāpa duḥkha tā ucyate kā punar saṃskāra duḥkha tā
translated: arises from greed and delusion. This is called the suffering of pain. What is the suffering of the formative forces?

original: sukhānubhavāt sukhasaṃskārāśayo duḥkhānubhavād api duḥkhasaṃskārāśaya iti / evaṃ karmabhyo vipāke 'nubhūyamāne sukhe duḥkhe vā punaḥ karmāśayapracaya
analyzed: sukha anubhavāt sukha saṃskāra āśayaḥ duḥkha anubhavāt api duḥkha saṃskāra āśayaḥ iti evam karmabhyaḥ vipāke nubhūyamāne sukhe duḥkhe vā punar karma āśaya pracaya
translated: From the experience of pleasure, there is a residuum of the formative forces of pleasure. From the experience of pain, there is also a residuum of the formative forces of pain. Thus, when the results of actions are being experienced as pleasure or pain, the accumulation of the residua of action

original: evam idam anādi duḥkhasroto viprasṛtaṃ yoginam eva pratikūlātmakatvād udvejayati / kasmāt /
analyzed: evam idam anādi duḥkha srotaḥ viprasṛtam yoginam eva pratikūla ātmaka tvāt udvejayati kasmāt
translated: In this way, this beginningless stream of suffering spreads out, and only the yogi is distressed by it, because it has a nature that is contrary to his own. Why is that?

original: akṣipātrakalpo hi vidvān iti / yathorṇātantur akṣipātre nyastaḥ sparśena duḥkhayati na cānyeṣu gātrāvayaveṣu /
analyzed: akṣi pātra kalpaḥ hi vidvān iti yathā ūrṇā tantuḥ akṣi pātre nyastaḥ sparśena duḥkhayati na ca anyeṣu gātra avayaveṣu
translated: Because the wise one is like a bowl for the eyes. Just as a strand of wool placed in a bowl for the eyes causes pain by touch, but not in other parts of the body,

original: evam etāni duḥkhāny akṣipātrakalpaṃ yoginam eva kliśnanti netaraṃ pratipattāram /
analyzed: evam etāni duḥkhāni akṣi pātra kalpam yoginam eva kliśnanti na itaram pratipattāram
translated: Thus, these sufferings afflict only the yogi who is like a vessel of misfortune, not the other practitioner.

original: itaraṃ tu svakarmopahṛtaṃ duḥkham upāttam upāttaṃ tyajantaṃ tyaktaṃ tyaktam upādadānam
analyzed: itaram tu sva karma upahṛtam duḥkham upāttam upāttam tyajantam tyaktam tyaktam upādadānam
translated: But the other [person], when suffering is presented by his own karma, abandons what is taken up, and takes up what is abandoned.

original: anādivāsanāvicitrayā cittavṛttyā samantato 'nuviddham ivāvidyayā hātavya evāhaṃkāramamakārānupātinaṃ🔽jātaṃ jātaṃ bāhyādhyātmikobhayanimittās triparvāṇas tāpā anuplavante / tad evam anādinā
analyzed: anādi vāsanā vicitrayā citta vṛttyā samantataḥ nuviddham iva avidyayā hātavyaḥ eva ahaṃkāra mamakāra anupātinam  jātam jātam bāhya ādhyātmika ubhaya nimittāḥ tri parvāṇaḥ tāpāḥ anuplavante tat evam anādinā
translated: And he is as if pierced all around by the variegated mental activity of beginningless latent impressions, along with the egoism and possessiveness that are to be abandoned.

original: duḥkhasrotasā vyuhyamānam ātmānaṃ bhūtagrāmaṃ ca dṛṣṭvā yogī sarvaduḥkhakṣayakāraṇaṃ
analyzed: duḥkha srotasā vyuhyamānam ātmānam bhūta grāmam ca dṛṣṭvā yogī sarva duḥkha kṣaya kāraṇam
translated: As soon as he is born, the three-fold torments arising from external, internal, and both [external and internal] causes descend upon him. Thus, the yogi, seeing himself and the group of beings being carried away by the beginningless

original: samyagdarśanaṃ śaraṇaṃ prapadyata iti /
analyzed: samyak darśanam śaraṇam prapadyate iti
translated: stream of suffering, takes refuge in right view, which is the cause of the destruction of all suffering.

original: guṇavṛttivirodhāc ca duḥkham eva sarvaṃ vivekinaḥ / prakhyāpravṛttisthitirūpā buddhiguṇāḥ
analyzed: guṇa vṛtti virodhāt ca duḥkham eva sarvam vivekinaḥ prakhyā pravṛtti sthiti rūpāḥ buddhi guṇāḥ
translated: And for the discerning one, everything is suffering due to the conflict of the modifications of the gunas. The modifications of the intellect, which are of the nature of manifestation, activity, and stability,

original: parasparānugrahatantrī bhūtvā śāntaṃ ghoraṃ mūḍhaṃ vā pratyayaṃ triguṇam evārabhante /
analyzed: paraspara anugraha tantrī bhūtvā śāntam ghoram mūḍham vā pratyayam triguṇam eva ārabhante
translated: become the thread of mutual support and give rise to the three-fold impression, which is of the nature of the three gunas, namely, tranquil, violent, and deluded.

original: calaṃ ca guṇavṛttam iti kṣiprapariṇāmi cittam uktam / rūpātiśayā vṛttyatiśayāś ca
analyzed: calam ca guṇa vṛttam iti kṣipra pariṇāmi cittam uktam rūpa atiśayāḥ vṛtti atiśayāḥ ca
translated: And the modifications of the gunas are unstable, so the mind is said to be quickly changing. The modifications of form and the modifications of the gunas

original: paraspareṇa virudhyante /
analyzed: paraspareṇa virudhyante
translated: are mutually contradictory.

original: sāmānyāni tv atiśayaiḥ saha pravartante / evam ete guṇā itaretarāśrayeṇopārjitasukhaduḥkhamohapratyayāḥ sarve sarvarūpā bhavantīti /
analyzed: sāmānyāni tu atiśayaiḥ saha pravartante evam ete guṇāḥ itara itara āśrayeṇa upārjita sukha duḥkha moha pratyayāḥ sarve sarva rūpāḥ bhavanti iti
translated: But the universals occur together with the particulars. Thus, all these gunas, having attained pleasure, pain, and delusion through mutual dependence, become all forms.
