translated: In the great world of Brahmā, there are five classes of gods: Kumudas, Ribhus, Pratardanas, Anjanabhas, and

original: pracitābhā iti / ete mahābhūtavaśino dhyānāhārāḥ kalpasahasrāyuṣaḥ / prathame brahmaṇo
analyzed: pracita ābhāḥ iti ete mahābhūta vaśinaḥ dhyāna āhārāḥ kalpa sahasra āyuṣaḥ prathame brahmaṇaḥ
translated: Pracitabhas. They have power over the great elements, subsist on meditation, and live for a thousand kalpas. In the first world of Brahmā,

original: janaloke caturvidho devanikāyo brahmapurohitā brahmakāyikā brahmamahākāyikā amarā
analyzed: jana loke caturvidhaḥ deva nikāyaḥ brahma purohitāḥ brahmakāyikāḥ brahmamahākāyikāḥ amarāḥ
translated: in the realm of Brahmā's people, there are four classes of gods: Brahmapurohitas, Brahmakāyikas, Brahmapurohitas, and Amaras.

original: iti / te bhūtendriyavaśino dviguṇadviguṇottarāyuñaḥ /
analyzed: iti te bhūta indriya vaśinaḥ dviguṇa dviguṇa uttara āyuñaḥ
translated: They have power over the elements and senses, and their lifespans double in length.

original: dvitīye tapasi loke trividho devanikāyaḥ ābhāsvarā mahābhāsvarāḥ satyamahābhāsvarā
analyzed: dvitīye tapasi loke trividhaḥ deva nikāyaḥ ābhāsvarāḥ mahābhāsvarāḥ satya mahābhāsvarā
translated: In the second world of austerities, there are three classes of gods: Ābhāsvaras, Mahābhasuras, and Satyabhasuras.

original: iti / te bhūtendriyaprakṛtivaśino dviguṇadviguṇottarāyuṣaḥ sarve dhyānāhārā ūrdhvaretasa
analyzed: iti te bhūta indriya prakṛti vaśinaḥ dviguṇa dviguṇa uttara āyuṣaḥ sarve dhyāna āhārāḥ ūrdhvaretasa
translated: Thus, they are masters of the elements, senses, and primordial nature, with lifespans twice as long as the previous ones, all subsisting on meditation, with upward-moving semen,

original: ūrdhvam apratihatajñānā adharabhūmiṣv anāvṛtajñānaviṣayāḥ / tṛtīye brahmaṇaḥ satyaloke
analyzed: ūrdhvam a pratihata jñānāḥ adhara bhūmiṣu anāvṛta jñāna viṣayāḥ tṛtīye brahmaṇaḥ satya loke
translated: with unobstructed knowledge above, with knowledge of the lower realms unobstructed, in the third world of Brahmā, the world of truth,

original: catvāro devanikāyā akṛtabhavananyāsāḥ svapratiṣṭhā uparyuparisthitāḥ pradhānavaśino yāvat sargāyuṣaḥ /
analyzed: catvāraḥ devanikāyāḥ akṛta bhavana nyāsāḥ sva pratiṣṭhāḥ upari upari sthitāḥ pradhāna vaśinaḥ yāvat sarga āyuṣaḥ
translated: the four classes of gods, not having laid the foundation for existence, self-established, situated above and above, masters of primordial nature, with lifespans lasting until the end of creation.

original: tatrācyutāḥ savitarkadhyānasukhāḥ /
analyzed: tatra acyutāḥ sa vitarka dhyāna sukhāḥ
translated: Among them, the Acyutas have the bliss of meditation with discursive thought.

original: śuddhanivāsāḥ savicāradhyānasukhāḥ /
analyzed: śuddha nivāsāḥ sa vicāra dhyāna sukhāḥ
translated: The Śuddhāvāsa gods have the bliss of meditation with investigation.

original: satyābhā ānandamātradhyānasukhāḥ /
analyzed: satya ābhāḥ ānanda mātra dhyāna sukhāḥ
translated: The Satyābhās have the bliss of meditation on mere bliss.

original: saṃjñāsaṃjñinaś cāsmitāmātradhyānasukhāḥ / te 'pi trailokyamadhye pratitiṣṭhanti /
analyzed: saṃjñā saṃjñinaḥ ca asmitā mātra dhyāna sukhāḥ te trailokya madhye pratitiṣṭhanti
translated: The Saṃjñāsaṃjñinas have the bliss of meditation on mere self-identification. They also abide in the middle of the three worlds.

original: ta ete sapta lokāḥ sarva eva brahmalokāḥ / videhaprakṛtilayās tu mokṣapade vartanta
analyzed: te ete sapta lokāḥ sarve eva brahma lokāḥ videha prakṛti layāḥ tu mokṣa pade vartanta
translated: These seven worlds are all the worlds of Brahmā. But those who have attained the nature of being bodiless abide in the state of liberation,

original: iti na lokamadhye nyastā iti / etad yoginā sākṣātkaraṇīyaṃ sūryadvāre saṃyamaṃ kṛtvā /
analyzed: iti na loka madhye nyastāḥ iti etat yoginā sākṣāt karaṇīyam sūrya dvāre saṃyamam kṛtvā
translated: so they are not placed in the middle of the worlds. This is to be directly realized by the yogi, having practiced restraint through the door of the sun.

original: tato 'nyatrāpi evaṃ tāvad abhyased yāvad idaṃ sarvaṃ dṛṣṭam iti / /
analyzed: tatas nyatra api evam tāvat abhyaset yāvat idam sarvam dṛṣṭam iti
translated: Then he should practice in this way elsewhere also, until he has seen all this.

original: candre tārāvyūhajñānam // / //
translated: In the moon, the knowledge of the arrangement of the stars.

original: candre saṃyamaṃ kṛtvā tārāṇāṃ vyūhaṃ vijānīyāt / /
analyzed: candre saṃyamam kṛtvā tārāṇām vyūham vijānīyāt
translated: Having practised concentration on the moon, one should know the arrangement of the stars.

original: dhruve tadgatijñānam // / //
analyzed: dhruve tad gati jñānam
translated: In the polar star, the knowledge of their motion.

original: tato dhruve saṃyamaṃ kṛtvā tārāṇāṃ gatiṃ vijānīyāt ūrdhvavimāneṣu kṛtasaṃyamas tāni vijānīyāt / /
analyzed: tatas dhruve saṃyamam kṛtvā tārāṇām gatim vijānīyāt ūrdhva vimāneṣu kṛta saṃyamaḥ tāni vijānīyāt
translated: Then, having practised concentration on the polar star, one should know the motion of the stars. Having practised concentration on the upper spheres, one should know them.

original: nābhicakre kāyavyūhajñānam // / //🔽nābhicakre saṃyamaṃ kṛtvā kāyavyūhaṃ vijānīyāt vātapittaśleṣmāṇas trayo doṣāḥ / dhātavaḥ sapta tvaglohitamāṃsasnāyvasthimajjāśukrāṇi pūrvaṃ
analyzed: nābhi cakre saṃyamam kṛtvā kāya vyūham vijānīyāt vāta pitta śleṣmāṇaḥ trayaḥ doṣāḥ dhātavaḥ sapta tvak lohita māṃsa snāyu asthi majjā śukrāṇi pūrvam
translated: In the navel cakra, the knowledge of the arrangement of the body.

original: pūrvam eṣāṃ bāhyam ity eṣa vinyāsaḥ / /
analyzed: pūrvam eṣām bāhyam iti eṣa vinyāsaḥ
translated: Having practised concentration in the navel cakra, one should know the arrangement of the body. The three humors are wind, bile, and phlegm. The seven constituents are skin, blood, flesh, sinews, bones, marrow, and semen. The earlier ones are external to the later ones. This is the arrangement.

original: kaṇṭhakūpe kṣutpipāsānivṛttiḥ // / //
translated: In the throat cavity, the cessation of hunger and thirst.

original: jihvāyā adhastāt tantus tantor adhastāt kaṇṭhas tato 'dhastāt kūpas tatra saṃyamāt kṣutpipāse na bādhete / /
analyzed: jihvāyāḥ adhastāt tantuḥ tantoḥ adhastāt kaṇṭhaḥ tatas dhastāt kūpaḥ tatra saṃyamāt kṣudh pipāse na bādhete
translated: Below the tongue is a thread, below the thread is the throat, below that is the cavity. By concentration on that, hunger and thirst do not afflict.

original: kūrmanāḍyāṃ sthairyam // / //
analyzed: kūrmanāḍyām sthairyam
translated: In the tortoise channel, stability.

original: kūpād adha urasi kūrmākārā nāḍī /
analyzed: kūpāt adhas urasi kūrma ākārā nāḍī
translated: Below the cavity, on the chest, is a channel shaped like a tortoise.

original: tasyāṃ kṛtasaṃyamaḥ sthirapadaṃ labhate yathā sarpo godhā veti / /
analyzed: tasyām kṛta saṃyamaḥ sthira padam labhate yathā sarpaḥ godhā vā iti
translated: One who has practised concentration on that attains a firm footing, like a snake or a lizard.

original: mūrdhajyotiṣi siddhadarśanam // / //
translated: In the light of the head, the perception of the Siddhas.

original: śiraḥkapāle 'ntaś chidraṃ prabhāsvaraṃ jyotis tatra saṃyamaṃ kṛtvā siddhānāṃ dyāvāpṛthivyor antarālacāriṇāṃ darśanam / /
analyzed: śiraḥ kapāle ntar chidram prabhāsvaram jyotiḥ tatra saṃyamam kṛtvā siddhānām dyāvāpṛthivyoḥ antarāla cāriṇām darśanam
translated: In the skull, there is an inner cavity, a luminous light. By concentrating on that, one perceives the Siddhas who move in the space between heaven and earth.

original: prātibhād vā sarvam // / //
analyzed: prātibhāt vā sarvam
translated: Or by the intuitive knowledge, everything...

original: prātibhaṃ nāma tārakaṃ tadvivekajasya jñānasya pūrvarūpam / yathodaye prabhā bhāskarasya / tena vā sarvam eva jānāti yogī prātibhasya jñānasyotpattāv
analyzed: prātibham nāma tārakam tad viveka jasya jñānasya pūrvarūpam yathā udaye prabhā bhāskarasya tena vā sarvam eva jānāti yogī prātibhasya jñānasya utpattau
translated: The intuitive knowledge is the forerunner of the knowledge born of discrimination, like the radiance of the sun at dawn. By that, the yogi knows everything at the arising of intuitive knowledge.

original: iti / /
analyzed: iti
translated: Thus.

original: hṛdaye cittasaṃvit // / //
analyzed: hṛdaye citta saṃvid
translated: And in the heart, the knowledge of the mind...

original: yad idam asmin brahmapure daharaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ veśma tatra vijñānaṃ tasmin saṃyamāc cittasaṃvit / /
analyzed: yat idam asmin brahma pure daharam puṇḍarīkam veśma tatra vijñānam tasmin saṃyamāt citta saṃvid
translated: This is the knowledge of the mind in the control of that knowledge in the small lotus house in this city of Brahman. There, by the control of that, there is the knowledge of the mind.

original: sattvapuruṣayor atyantāsaṃkīrṇayoḥ pratyayāviśeṣo bhogaḥ parārthāt svārthasaṃyamāt puruṣajñānam // / //
analyzed: sattva puruṣayoḥ atyanta asaṃkīrṇayoḥ pratyaya aviśeṣaḥ bhogaḥ para arthāt sva artha saṃyamāt puruṣa jñānam
translated: The experience of the non-difference of the absolutely unmixed sattva and purusha is enjoyment. From the control of one's own purpose through the purpose of another, there is the knowledge of purusha...

original: buddhisattvaṃ prakhyāśīlaṃ samānasattvopanibandhane rajastamasī vaśīkṛtya sattvapuruṣānyatāpratyayena
analyzed: buddhi sattvam prakhyā śīlam samāna sattva upanibandhane rajaḥ tamasī vaśīkṛtya sattva puruṣa anya tā pratyayena
translated: Having subdued rajas and tamas in the attachment to the same substance, the mind-stuff which is of the nature of manifestation, by the idea of the difference of sattva and purusha,

original: pariṇatam / tasmāc ca sattvāt pariṇāmino 'tyantavidharmā viśuddho 'nyaś citimātrarūpaḥ
analyzed: pariṇatam tasmāt ca sattvāt tyanta vidharmā viśuddhaḥ citi mātra rūpaḥ
translated: And from that evolving entity, the absolutely different, pure, consciousness-only-formed Purusha.

original: puruṣaḥ / tayor atyantāsaṃkīrṇayoḥ pratyayāviśeṣo bhogaḥ puruṣasya darśitaviṣayatvāt
analyzed: puruṣaḥ tayoḥ atyanta asaṃkīrṇayoḥ pratyaya aviśeṣaḥ bhogaḥ puruṣasya darśita viṣaya tvāt
translated: Of those two, absolutely unmixed, the experience is a particular condition for the Purusha, because the object is shown.

original: sa bhogapratyayaḥ sattvasya parārthatvād dṛśyaḥ /
analyzed: sa bhoga pratyayaḥ sattvasya parārtha tvāt dṛśyaḥ
translated: That experience-condition of the being is visible, because it is for the sake of another.

original: yas tu tasmād viśiṣṭaś citimātrarūpo 'nyaḥ pauruṣeyaḥ pratyayas tatra saṃyamāt puruṣaviṣayā
analyzed: yaḥ tu tasmāt viśiṣṭaḥ citi mātra rūpaḥ pauruṣeyaḥ pratyayaḥ tatra saṃyamāt puruṣa viṣayā
translated: But the other, which is superior to that, the consciousness-only-formed human condition, from concentration on that, knowledge with the Purusha as its object

original: prajñā jāyate / na ca puruṣapratyayena buddhisattvātmanā puruṣo dṛśyate puruṣa eva
analyzed: prajñā jāyate na ca puruṣa pratyayena buddhi sattva ātmanā puruṣaḥ dṛśyate puruṣaḥ eva
translated: is produced. And the Purusha is not seen by the human condition in the form of the mind-stuff. The Purusha himself

original: taṃ pratyayaṃ svātmāvalambanaṃ paśyati tathā hy uktam vijñātāram are kena vijānīyāt iti / /🔽tataḥ prātibhaśrāvaṇavedanādarśāsvādavārtā jāyante // / //
analyzed: tam pratyayam sva ātma avalambanam paśyati tathā hi uktam vijñātāram are kena vijānīyāt iti  tatas prātibha śrāvaṇa vedana ādarśa āsvāda vārtāḥ jāyante
translated: sees that condition as having its own self as its support. For it is said: By what can one know the knower?🔽Then, from that, there arise the knowledge of the intellect, hearing, feeling, seeing, tasting, and communication.

original: prātibhāt sūkṣmavyavahitaviprakṛṣṭātītānāgatajñānam / śrāvaṇād divyaśabdaśravaṇam /
analyzed: prātibhāt sūkṣma vyavahita viprakṛṣṭa atīta anāgata jñānam śrāvaṇāt divya śabda śravaṇam
translated: From the knowledge of the intellect, there is knowledge of the subtle, the obstructed, the distant, the past, and the future. From hearing, there is hearing of divine sounds.

original: vedanād divyasparśādhigamaḥ / ādarśād divyarūpasaṃvit āsvādād divyarasasaṃvit vārtāto
analyzed: vedanāt divya sparśa adhigamaḥ ādarśāt divya rūpa saṃvid āsvādāt divya rasa saṃvid vārtātaḥ
translated: From the Veda, the attainment of divine touch. From the mirror, the knowledge of divine form. From taste, the knowledge of divine taste. From conversation,

original: divyagandhavijñānam ity etāni nityaṃ jāyante / /
analyzed: divya gandha vijñānam iti etāni nityam jāyante
translated: the knowledge of divine smell. These are always produced.

original: te samādhāv upasargā vyutthāne siddhayaḥ // / //
analyzed: te samādhau upasargāḥ vyutthāne siddhayaḥ
translated: These are obstacles in concentration, but accomplishments in emergence.

original: te prātibhādayaḥ samāhitacittasyotpadyamānā upasargās taddarśanapratyanīkatvāt vyutthitacittasyotpadyamānāḥ siddhayaḥ / /
analyzed: te prātibha ādayaḥ samāhita cittasya utpadyamānāḥ upasargāḥ tad darśana pratyanīka tvāt vyutthita cittasya utpadyamānāḥ siddhayaḥ
translated: These, beginning with clairvoyance, when produced in one whose mind is concentrated, are obstacles, because they are counteracted by the vision of that [concentration]. When produced in one whose mind is emerged, they are accomplishments.

original: bandhakāraṇaśaithilyāt pracārasaṃvedanāc ca cittasya paraśarīrāveśaḥ // / //
analyzed: bandha kāraṇa śaithilyāt pracāra saṃvedanāt ca cittasya para śarīra āveśaḥ
translated: The entry of the mind into another's body is due to the loosening of the cause of bondage and the awareness of its activity.

original: lolībhūtasya manaso 'pratiṣṭhasya śarīre karmāśayavaśād bandhaḥ pratiṣṭhety arthaḥ🔽tasya karmaṇo bandhakāraṇasya śaithilyaṃ samādhibalād bhavati / pracārasaṃvedanaṃ
analyzed: lolībhūtasya pratiṣṭhasya śarīre karma āśaya vaśāt bandhaḥ pratiṣṭhā iti arthaḥ  tasya karmaṇaḥ bandha kāraṇasya śaithilyam samādhi balāt bhavati pracāra saṃvedanam
translated: The mind, which is unsteady and has no support in the body, is bound by the power of the store of karma. The meaning is that it has support.🔽The loosening of that karma, which is the cause of bondage, occurs by the power of concentration. And the awareness of the activity of the mind

original: ca cittasya samādhijam eva karmabandhakṣayāt svacittasya pracārasaṃvedanāc ca yogī
analyzed: ca cittasya samādhi jam eva karma bandha kṣayāt sva cittasya pracāra saṃvedanāt ca yogī
translated: is due to the destruction of the bondage of karma, which is produced by concentration itself. And because of the awareness of the activity of one's own mind, the yogi

original: cittaṃ svaśarīrān niṣkṛṣya śarīrāntareṣu nikṣipati / nikṣiptaṃ cittaṃ cendriyāṇy anu
analyzed: cittam sva śarīrāt niṣkṛṣya śarīra antareṣu nikṣipati nikṣiptam cittam ca indriyāṇi anu
translated: Having drawn out the mind from his own body, he deposits it in other bodies. And the mind being deposited, the senses follow it.

original: patanti / yathā madhukararājānaṃ makṣikā utpatantam anūtpatanti niviśamānam anu niviśante
analyzed: patanti yathā madhukara rājānam makṣikāḥ utpatantam anūtpatanti niviśamānam anu niviśante
translated: Just as when the king of bees flies up, the bees fly up after him, and when he settles down, they settle down after him.

original: tathendriyāṇi paraśarīrāveśe cittam anu vidhīyanta iti / /
analyzed: tathā indriyāṇi para śarīra āveśe cittam anu vidhīyante iti
translated: In the same way, when the mind enters another's body, the senses follow the mind.

original: udānajayāj jalapaṅkakaṇṭakādiṣv asaṅga utkrāntiś ca // / //
analyzed: udāna jayāt jala paṅka kaṇṭaka ādiṣu asaṅgaḥ utkrāntiḥ ca
translated: By the conquest of udāna, there is non-attachment to water, mud, thorns, etc., and rising up.

original: samastendriyavṛttiḥ prāṇādilakṣaṇā jīvanaṃ /
translated: Life is the function of all the senses characterized by prāṇa etc.

original: tasya kriyā pañcatayī prāṇo mukhanāsikāgatir āhṛdayavṛttiḥ / samaṃ nayanāt samānaś
analyzed: tasya kriyā pañcatayī prāṇaḥ mukha nāsikā gatiḥ āhṛdayavṛttiḥ samam nayanāt samānaḥ
translated: Its action is fivefold: Prāṇa is the movement through the mouth and nose, functioning up to the heart. Samāna is so called because it carries equally.

original: cānābhivṛttiḥ / apanayanād apāna āpādatalavṛttiḥ unnayanād udāna āśirovṛttiḥ vyāpī
analyzed: cāna abhivṛttiḥ apanayanāt apānaḥ ā pāda tala vṛttiḥ unnayanāt udānaḥ ā śiraḥ vṛttiḥ vyāpī
translated: It functions up to the navel. Apāna is so called because it carries downward, functioning from the soles of the feet. Udāna is so called because it carries upward, functioning up to the head. Vyāna is so called because it pervades.

original: vyāna iti / eṣāṃ pradhānaṃ prāṇaḥ udānajayāj jalapaṅkakaṇṭakādiṣv asaṅga utkrāntiś
analyzed: vyānaḥ iti eṣām pradhānam prāṇaḥ udāna jayāt jala paṅka kaṇṭaka ādiṣu asaṅgaḥ utkrāntiḥ
translated: Among these, prāṇa is the principal one. By the conquest of udāna, there is non-attachment to water, mud, thorns, etc., and rising up.

original: ca prāyaṇakāle bhavati tāṃ vaśitvena pratipadyate / /
analyzed: ca prāyaṇa kāle bhavati tām vaśi tvena pratipadyate
translated: At the time of death, one attains mastery over that.

original: samānajayāj jvalanam // / //
analyzed: samāna jayāt jvalanam
translated: By the conquest of samāna, there is blazing.

original: jitasamānas tejasa upadhmānaṃ kṛtvā jvalayati / /
analyzed: jita samānaḥ tejasaḥ upadhmānam kṛtvā jvalayati
translated: Having conquered the equal, it blazes by blowing on its own energy.

original: śrotrākāśayoḥ saṃbandhasaṃyamād divyaṃ śrotram // / //
analyzed: śrotra ākāśayoḥ saṃbandha saṃyamāt divyam śrotram
translated: By the restraint of the connection between the ear and space, there is divine hearing.

original: sarvaśrotrāṇām ākāśaṃ pratiṣṭhā sarvaśabdānāṃ ca yathoktam tulyadeśaśravaṇānām ekadeśaśrutitvaṃ sarveṣāṃ bhavatīti tac caitad ākāśasya
analyzed: sarva śrotrāṇām ākāśam pratiṣṭhā sarva śabdānām ca yathā uktam tulya deśa śravaṇānām eka deśa śruti tvam sarveṣām bhavati iti tat ca etat ākāśasya
translated: Space is the basis of all ears and all sounds, as stated. The state of being heard in one place of all those heard in the same place occurs. And this is said to be the non-obstruction of space.

original: anāvaraṇaṃ coktam / tathāmūrtasyānāvaraṇadarśanād vibhutvam api prakhyātam ākāśasya /
analyzed: anāvaraṇam ca uktam tathā amūrtasya anāvaraṇa darśanāt vibhu tvam api prakhyātam ākāśasya
translated: And because the unseen is seen to be unobstructed, the all-pervasiveness of space is also well-known.

original: śabdagrahaṇānumitaṃ śrotram / badhirābadhirayor ekaḥ śabdaṃ gṛhṇāty aparo na gṛhṇātīti
analyzed: śabda grahaṇa anumitam śrotram badhira abadhirayoḥ ekaḥ śabdam gṛhṇāti aparaḥ na gṛhṇāti iti
translated: The ear is inferred from the apprehension of sound. One of the deaf and the not-deaf apprehends sound, the other does not.

original: tasmāc chrotram eva śabdaviṣayam śrotrākāśayoḥ saṃbandhe kṛtasaṃyamasya yogino divyaṃ
analyzed: tasmāt śrotram eva śabda viṣayam śrotra ākāśayoḥ saṃbandhe kṛta saṃyamasya yoginaḥ divyam
translated: Therefore, the ear alone has sound as its object. For the yogi who has restrained the connection between the ear and space, divine

original: śrotraṃ pravartate / /
analyzed: śrotram pravartate
translated: hearing arises.

original: kāyākāśayoḥ saṃbandhasaṃyamāl laghutūlasamāpatteś cākāśagamanam // / //
analyzed: kāya ākāśayoḥ saṃbandha saṃyamāt laghu tūla samāpatteḥ ca ākāśagamanam
translated: By the restraint of the connection between the body and space, and by the attainment of lightness like cotton, there is movement in space.

original: yatra kāyas tatrākāśaṃ tasyāvakāśadānāt kāyasya tena saṃbandhaḥ prāptis tatra kṛtasaṃyamo
analyzed: yatra kāyaḥ tatra ākāśam tasya avakāśa dānāt kāyasya tena saṃbandhaḥ prāptiḥ tatra kṛta saṃyamaḥ
translated: Where there is the body, there is space, because it gives room for it. The connection of the body with it is the attainment. Having restrained the mind there,🔽the yogi attains lightness like cotton and moves in space.

original: jitvā tatsaṃbandhaṃ laghuṣu vā tūlādiṣv ā paramāṇubhyaḥ samāpattiṃ labdhvā jitasaṃbandho
analyzed: jitvā tad saṃbandham laghuṣu vā tūla ādiṣu ā paramāṇubhyaḥ samāpattim labdhvā jita saṃbandhaḥ
translated: Having conquered that connection, or having attained mastery over light things like cotton, etc., up to the atoms, he who has conquered the connection

original: laghur bhavati / laghutvāc ca jale pādābhyāṃ viharati tatas tūrṇanābhitantumātre vihṛtya
analyzed: laghuḥ bhavati laghu tvāt ca jale pādābhyām viharati tatas tu ūrṇanābhi tantu mātre vihṛtya
translated: becomes light. And because of lightness, he moves about on the water with his feet. Then, having moved about in the space of a moment,

original: raśmiṣu viharati tato yatheṣṭam ākāśagatir asya bhavatīti / /
analyzed: raśmiṣu viharati tatas yatheṣṭam ākāśa gatiḥ asya bhavati iti
translated: he moves about in the rays. Then he has the power of going through space as he wishes.

original: bahir akalpitā vṛttir mahāvidehā tataḥ prakāśāvaraṇakṣayaḥ // / //🔽śarīrād bahir manaso vṛttilābho videhā nāma dhāraṇā / sā yadi śarīrapratiṣṭhasya manaso
analyzed: bahis akalpitā vṛttiḥ mahāvidehā tatas prakāśa āvaraṇa kṣayaḥ  śarīrāt bahis manasaḥ vṛtti lābhaḥ videhā nāma dhāraṇā sā yadi śarīra pratiṣṭhasya manasaḥ
translated: The function outside without conceptualization is Mahāvideha. Then there is the destruction of the obscuration of light.🔽The attainment of the function of the mind outside the body is called Videha. If that is said to be conceptualized when the function of the mind residing in the body

original: bahirvṛttimātreṇa bhavati sā kalpitety ucyate / yā tu śarīranirapekṣā bahirbhūtasyaiva
analyzed: bahis vṛtti mātreṇa bhavati sā kalpitā iti ucyate yā tu śarīra nirapekṣā bahis bhūtasya eva
translated: is merely external, but when the mind that has become external is independent of the body and

original: manaso bahirvṛttiḥ sā khalv akalpitā tatra kalpitayā sādhayanty akalpitāṃ mahāvidehām
analyzed: manasaḥ bahis vṛttiḥ sā khalu a kalpitā tatra kalpitayā sādhayanti a kalpitām mahāvidehām
translated: has an external function, that is indeed non-conceptual. There, they who accomplish the non-conceptual Mahāvideha with the conceptual one

original: iti / yayā paraśarīrāṇy āviśanti yoginaḥ /
analyzed: iti yayā para śarīrāṇi āviśanti yoginaḥ
translated: by which the yogis enter the bodies of others.

original: tataś ca dhāraṇātaḥ prakāśātmano buddhisattvasya yadāvaraṇaṃ kleśakarmavipākatrayaṃ rajastamomūlaṃ tasya ca kṣayo bhavati / /
analyzed: tatas ca dhāraṇātaḥ prakāśa ātmanaḥ buddhi sattvasya yat āvaraṇam kleśa karma vipāka trayam rajaḥ tamaḥ mūlam tasya ca kṣayaḥ bhavati
translated: And then, from the practice of concentration, there is the destruction of the three-fold obscuration of the intellect, which consists of the afflictions, actions and their results, and which has rajas and tamas for its root.

original: sthūlasvarūpasūkṣmānvayārthavattvasaṃyamād bhūtajayaḥ // / //
translated: By the practice of concentration on the gross, the subtle, the causal, and the useful, there is mastery over the elements.

original: tatra pārthivādyāḥ śabdādayo viśeṣāḥ sahākārādibhir dharmaiḥ sthūlaśabdena paribhāṣitāḥ
analyzed: tatra pārthiva ādyāḥ śabda ādayaḥ viśeṣāḥ saha ākāra ādibhiḥ dharmaiḥ sthūla śabdena paribhāṣitāḥ
translated: There, the specific qualities such as sound, etc. of earth, etc., along with the qualities such as color, etc., are designated by the word gross.

original: etad bhūtānāṃ prathamaṃ rūpam / dvitīyaṃ rūpaṃ svasāmānyaṃ mūrtir bhūmiḥ sneho jalaṃ
analyzed: etat bhūtānām prathamam rūpam dvitīyam rūpam sva sāmānyam mūrtiḥ bhūmiḥ snehaḥ jalam
translated: This is the first form of the elements. The second form is their own generality, which is said to be the subtle form.

original: vahnir uṣṇatā vāyuḥ praṇāmī sarvatogatir ākāśa ity etat svarūpaśabdenocyate /
analyzed: vahniḥ uṣṇa tā vāyuḥ praṇāmī sarvatas gatiḥ ākāśaḥ iti etat svarūpa śabdena ucyate
translated: The earth is solidity, water is fluidity, fire is heat, air is motion, and space is omnipresence. This is called the subtle form.

original: asya sāmānyasya śabdādayo viśeṣāḥ tathā coktam ekajātisamanvitānām eṣāṃ dharmamātravyāvṛttir iti /
analyzed: asya sāmānyasya śabda ādayaḥ viśeṣāḥ tathā ca uktam eka jāti samanvitānām eṣām dharma mātra vyāvṛttiḥ iti
translated: And it is said that sound, etc. are the specific qualities of this generality, and that they are distinguished only by their qualities, being endowed with the same genus.

original: sāmānyaviśeṣasamudāyo 'tra dravyam / dviṣṭho hi samūhaḥ pratyastamitabhedāvayavānugataḥ śarīraṃ vṛkṣo yūthaṃ vanam iti /
analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa samudāyaḥ tra dravyam dviṣṭhaḥ hi samūhaḥ pratyasta mita bheda avayava anugataḥ śarīram vṛkṣaḥ yūtham vanam iti
translated: Here, substance is the aggregate of generality and particularity, for an aggregate is twofold, following the undifferentiated parts, like a body, a tree, a herd, or a forest.

original: śabdenopāttabhedāvayavānugataḥ samūha ubhaye devamanuṣyāḥ samūhasya devā eko bhāgo manuṣyā dvitīyo bhāgas tābhyām evābhidhīyate samūhaḥ /
analyzed: śabdena upātta bheda avayava anugataḥ samūhaḥ ubhaye deva manuṣyāḥ samūhasya devāḥ ekaḥ bhāgaḥ manuṣyāḥ dvitīyaḥ bhāgaḥ tābhyām eva abhidhīyate samūhaḥ
translated: The collection that inheres in the parts that are distinguished by sound is both gods and humans. The collection is designated by just those two, gods being one part and humans the second part.

original: sa ca bhedābhedavivakṣitaḥ / āmrāṇāṃ vanaṃ brāhmaṇānāṃ saṃgha āmravaṇaṃ brāhmaṇasaṃgha iti /
analyzed: sa ca bheda abheda vivakṣitaḥ āmrāṇām vanam brāhmaṇānām saṃghaḥ āmravaṇam brāhmaṇa saṃghaḥ iti
translated: And that is intended to be distinguished and not distinguished, like a forest of mango trees, an assembly of Brahmins, a forest of mango trees, an assembly of Brahmins.

original: sa punar dvividho yutasiddhāvayavo 'yutasiddhāvayavaś ca / yutasiddhāvayavaḥ samūho🔽vanaṃ saṃgha iti ayutasiddhāvayavaḥ saṃghātaḥ śarīraṃ vṛkṣaḥ paramāṇur iti / ayutasiddhāvayavabhedānugataḥ
analyzed: sa punar dvividhaḥ yuta siddha avayavaḥ yuta siddha avayavaḥ ca yuta siddha avayavaḥ samūhaḥ  vanam saṃghaḥ iti ayuta siddha avayavaḥ saṃghātaḥ śarīram vṛkṣaḥ paramāṇuḥ iti ayuta siddha avayava bheda anugataḥ
translated: Moreover, that is twofold: having parts that are simultaneously existent and having parts that are not simultaneously existent. A collection having parts that are simultaneously existent is

original: samūho dravyam iti patañjaliḥ etat svarūpam ity uktam /
analyzed: samūhaḥ dravyam iti patañjaliḥ etat svarūpam iti uktam
translated: a forest, an assembly. A collection having parts that are not simultaneously existent is a composite, a body, a tree, an atom. Patanjali says that a collection that inheres in the distinction of parts that are not simultaneously existent is a substance. This is said to be its nature.

original: atha kim eṣāṃ sūkṣmarūpaṃ /
analyzed: atha kim eṣām sūkṣma rūpam
translated: Now, what is their subtle nature?

original: tanmātraṃ bhūtakāraṇaṃ /
analyzed: tanmātram bhūta kāraṇam
translated: The subtle elements are the cause of the gross elements.

original: tasyaiko 'vayavaḥ paramāṇuḥ sāmānyaviśeṣātmāyutasiddhāvayavabhedānugataḥ samudāya
analyzed: tasya ekaḥ vayavaḥ paramāṇuḥ sāmānya viśeṣa ātma ayuta siddha avayava bheda anugataḥ samudāya
translated: One part of that is an atom, which has the nature of a universal and particular, and inheres in the distinction of parts that are not simultaneously existent. A collection

original: ity evaṃ sarvatanmātrāṇy etat tṛtīyam / atha bhūtānāṃ caturthaṃ rūpaṃ khyātikriyāsthitiśīlā
analyzed: iti evam sarva tanmātrāṇi etat tṛtīyam atha bhūtānām caturtham rūpam khyāti kriyā sthiti śīlā
translated: is thus all the subtle elements, this is the third. Now, the fourth nature of the gross elements is characterized by manifestation, action, and stability.

original: guṇāḥ kāryasvabhāvānupātino 'nvayaśabdenoktāḥ / athaiṣāṃ pañcamaṃ rūpam arthavattvaṃ /
analyzed: guṇāḥ kārya svabhāva anupātinaḥ nvaya śabdena uktāḥ atha eṣām pañcamam rūpam arthavat tvam
translated: The qualities, which follow the nature of their effects, are called the 'concomitants'. Now, the fifth form of these is 'purposefulness'.

original: bhogāpavargārthatā guṇeṣv evānvayinī /
analyzed: bhoga apavarga artha tā guṇeṣu eva anvayinī
translated: The purposefulness of the qualities is to be for the enjoyment and liberation of the soul.

original: guṇās tanmātrabhūtabhautikeṣv iti sarvam arthavat / teṣv idānīṃ bhūteṣu pañcasu pañcarūpeṣu🔽saṃyamāt tasya tasya rūpasya svarūpadarśanaṃ jayaś ca prādurbhavati / tatra pañca
analyzed: guṇāḥ tanmātra bhūta bhautikeṣu iti sarvam arthavat teṣu idānīm bhūteṣu pañcasu pañca rūpeṣu  saṃyamāt tasya tasya rūpasya sva rūpa darśanam jayaḥ ca prādurbhavati tatra pañca
translated: The qualities are in the subtle elements and the gross elements. Thus, everything is purposeful. Now, in those five elements with five forms,

original: bhūtasvarūpāṇi jitvā bhūtajayī bhavati tajjayād vatsānusāriṇya iva gāvo 'sya saṃkalpānuvidhāyinyo🔽bhūtaprakṛtayo bhavanti / /
analyzed: bhūta svarūpāṇi jitvā bhūta jayī bhavati tad jayāt vatsa anusāriṇyaḥ iva gāvaḥ saṃkalpa anuvidhāyinyaḥ  bhūta prakṛtayaḥ bhavanti
translated: by restraint, the vision of the nature of each form and victory arise. There, having conquered the natures of the five elements, one becomes a conqueror of the elements. By that conquest, the elemental principles become obedient to one's will, like cows following a calf.

original: tato 'ṇimādiprādurbhāvaḥ kāyasaṃpat taddharmānabhighātaś ca // / //
analyzed: tatas ṇima ādi prādurbhāvaḥ kāya saṃpad tad dharma anabhighātaḥ ca
translated: Then, the manifestation of the powers of minuteness etc., the perfection of the body, and the non-obstruction of its qualities occur.

original: tatrāṇimā bhavaty aṇuḥ laghimā laghur bhavati mahimā mahān bhavati / prāptir aṅgulyagreṇāpi
analyzed: tatra aṇimā bhavati aṇuḥ laghimā laghuḥ bhavati mahimā mahān bhavati prāptiḥ aṅguli agreṇa api
translated: Among them, one becomes minute, having the power of minuteness. One becomes light, having the power of lightness. One becomes great, having the power of greatness. One reaches, touching even the moon with the tip of one's finger.

original: spṛśati candramasam / prākāmyam icchānabhighātaḥ bhūmāv unmajjati nimajjati yathodake /
analyzed: spṛśati candramasam prākāmyam icchā an abhighātaḥ bhūmau unmajjati nimajjati yathā udake
translated: One's desires are not obstructed, having the power of desire. One dives in and out of the earth as if in water.

original: vaśitvaṃ bhūtabhautikeṣu vaśī bhavaty avaśyaś cānyeṣām īśitṛtvaṃ teṣāṃ prabhavāpyayavyūhānām🔽īṣṭe / yatra kāmāvasāyitvaṃ satyasaṃkalpatā yathā saṃkalpas tathā bhūtaprakṛtīnām🔽avasthānam / na ca śakto 'pi padārthaviparyāsaṃ karoti kasmāt anyasya yatra kāmāvasāyinaḥ
analyzed: vaśi tvam bhūta bhautikeṣu vaśī bhavati avaśyaḥ ca anyeṣām īśitṛ tvam teṣām prabhava apyaya vyūhānām  īṣṭe yatra kāmāvasāyi tvam satya saṃkalpa tā yathā saṃkalpaḥ tathā bhūta prakṛtīnām  avasthānam na ca padārtha viparyāsam karoti kasmāt anyasya yatra kāmāvasāyinaḥ
translated: Mastery is the ability to control material things and others control them.

original: pūrvasiddhasya tathā bhūteṣu saṃkalpād iti / etāny aṣṭāv aiśvaryāṇi /
analyzed: pūrva siddhasya tathā bhūteṣu saṃkalpāt iti etāni aṣṭau aiśvaryāṇi
translated: He desires, where there is the ability to will, the ability to resolve, the ability to transform things according to his will. The elements remain as he resolves them, and he does not transform things into something else, although able to do so. Why? Because of the prior establishment of others who have the ability to will there. These are the eight masteries.

original: kāyasaṃpad vakṣyamāṇā taddharmānabhighātaś ca pṛthvī mūrtyā na niruṇaddhi yoginaḥ śarīrādikriyāṃ /
analyzed: kāya saṃpad vakṣyamāṇā tad dharma anabhighātaḥ ca pṛthvī mūrtyā na niruṇaddhi yoginaḥ śarīra ādi kriyām
translated: The perfection of the body will be explained later. The non-obstruction of its qualities is that the earth, as a material substance, does not obstruct the yogi's activities such as the body.

original: śilām apy anuviśatīti / nāpaḥ snigdhāḥ kledayanti nāgnir uṣṇo dahati na vāyuḥ praṇāmī vahati anāvaraṇātmake 'py ākāśe bhavaty āvṛtakāyaḥ siddhānām
analyzed: śilām api anuviśati iti na apaḥ snigdhāḥ kledayanti na agniḥ uṣṇaḥ dahati na vāyuḥ praṇāmī vahati anāvaraṇa ātmake pi ākāśe bhavati āvṛta kāyaḥ siddhānām
translated: It penetrates even a rock. Water, as moist, does not moisten. Fire, as hot, does not burn. Wind, as moving, does not move. Even in space, which has the nature of non-obstruction, the body becomes obstructed.

original: apy adṛśyo bhavati / /
analyzed: api adṛśyaḥ bhavati
translated: He becomes invisible even to the perfected beings.

original: rūpalāvaṇyabalavajrasaṃhananatvāni kāyasaṃpat // / //
analyzed: rūpa lāvaṇya bala vajra saṃhanana tvāni kāya saṃpad
translated: The perfection of the body is the possession of form, beauty, strength, and a body as hard as a diamond.

original: darśanīyaḥ kāntimān atiśayabalo vajrasaṃhananaś ceti / /
analyzed: darśanīyaḥ kāntimān atiśaya balaḥ vajra saṃhananaḥ ca iti
translated: He is handsome, beautiful, endowed with extraordinary strength, and has a body as hard as a thunderbolt.

original: grahaṇasvarūpāsmitānvayārthavattvasaṃyamād indriyajayaḥ // / //
translated: By the restraint of the grasping, the form, the I-am-ness, the continuity, the purpose, and the union, there is mastery over the senses.

original: sāmānyaviśeṣātmā śabdādir grāhyaḥ teṣv indriyāṇāṃ vṛttir grahaṇam / na ca tatsāmānyamātragrahaṇākāraṃ
analyzed: sāmānya viśeṣa ātmā śabda ādiḥ grāhyaḥ teṣu indriyāṇām vṛttiḥ grahaṇam na ca tad sāmānya mātra grahaṇa ākāram
translated: The object to be grasped consists of universals and particulars, such as sound etc. The function of the senses in relation to them is grasping. And that does not have the form of grasping only the universal.

original: katham anālocitaḥ sa viṣayaviśeṣa indriyeṇa manasānuvyavasīyeteti / svarūpaṃ punaḥ
analyzed: katham anālocitaḥ sa viṣaya viśeṣaḥ indriyeṇa manasā anuvyavasīyeta iti svarūpam punar
translated: How can that particular object, which is not contemplated, be determined by the mind through the senses? The form, again,

original: prakāśātmano buddhisattvasya sāmānyaviśeṣayor ayutasiddhāvayavabhedānugataḥ samūho
analyzed: prakāśa ātmanaḥ buddhi sattvasya sāmānya viśeṣayoḥ ayuta siddha avayava bheda anugataḥ samūhaḥ
translated: of the consciousness substance, which is of the nature of light, is a collection that follows the divisions of the inseparable components of the universal and the particular.

original: dravyam indriyam / teṣāṃ tṛtīyaṃ rūpam asmitālakṣaṇo 'haṃkāraḥ / tasya sāmānyasyendriyāṇi
analyzed: dravyam indriyam teṣām tṛtīyam rūpam asmitā lakṣaṇaḥ haṃkāraḥ tasya sāmānyasya indriyāṇi
translated: The substance is the sense organ. The third form of those is the egoity characterized by the I-am-ness. The senses are

original: viśeṣāḥ caturthaṃ rūpaṃ vyavasāyātmakāḥ prakāśakriyāsthitiśīlā guṇā yeṣām indriyāṇi
analyzed: viśeṣāḥ caturtham rūpam vyavasāya ātmakāḥ prakāśa kriyā sthiti śīlāḥ guṇāḥ yeṣām indriyāṇi
translated: the particulars of that universal. The fourth form is those whose nature is determination, which are the qualities that have the nature of manifestation, action, and stability. The senses

original: sāhaṃkārāṇi pariṇāmaḥ / pañcamaṃ rūpaṃ guṇeṣu yad anugataṃ puruṣārthavattvam iti /
analyzed: sa ahaṃkārāṇi pariṇāmaḥ pañcamam rūpam guṇeṣu yat anugatam puruṣa arthavat tvam iti
translated: are the transformation along with the egoity. The fifth form is the continuity in the qualities that is conducive to the purpose of the spirit.

original: pañcasv eteṣv indriyarūpeṣu yathākramaṃ saṃyamas tatra tatra jayaṃ kṛtvā pañcarūpajayād
analyzed: pañcasu eteṣu indriya rūpeṣu yathākramam saṃyamaḥ tatra tatra jayam kṛtvā pañca rūpa jayāt
translated: The restraint in these five forms of the sense organs, having conquered here and there, by the conquest of the five forms,

original: indriyajayaḥ prādurbhavati yoginaḥ / /
analyzed: indriya jayaḥ prādurbhavati yoginaḥ
translated: the conquest of the sense organs manifests for the yogi.

original: tato manojavitvaṃ vikaraṇabhāvaḥ pradhānajayaś ca // / //
analyzed: tatas manojavi tvam vikaraṇa bhāvaḥ pradhāna jayaḥ ca
translated: Then, the state of having the speed of mind, the state of being able to transform, and the conquest of Prakriti...

original: kāyasyānuttamo gatilābho manojavitvam / videhānām indriyāṇām abhipretadeśakālaviṣayāpekṣo
analyzed: kāyasya anuttamaḥ gati lābhaḥ manojavi tvam videhānām indriyāṇām abhipreta deśa kāla viṣaya apekṣaḥ
translated: The attainment of the highest speed of the body is having the speed of mind. The attainment of function by the disembodied sense organs, in accordance with the desired place, time, and object,

original: vṛttilābho vikaraṇabhāvaḥ / sarvaprakṛtivikāravaśitvaṃ pradhānajaya ity etās tisraḥ
analyzed: vṛtti lābhaḥ vikaraṇa bhāvaḥ sarva prakṛti vikāra vaśitvam pradhāna jayaḥ iti etāḥ tisraḥ
translated: is the state of being able to transform. Mastery over all Prakriti and its evolutes is the conquest of Prakriti. These three

original: siddhayo madhupratīkā ucyante etāś ca karaṇapañcarūpajayād adhigamyante / /
analyzed: siddhayaḥ madhupratīkāḥ ucyante etāḥ ca karaṇa pañca rūpa jayāt adhigamyante
translated: accomplishments are said to be symbolized by honey. And these are attained by the conquest of the five forms of the sense organs.

original: sattvapuruṣānyatākhyātimātrasya sarvabhāvādhiṣṭhātṛtvaṃ sarvajñātṛtvaṃ ca // / //
analyzed: sattva puruṣa anya tā khyāti mātrasya sarva bhāva adhiṣṭhātṛ tvam sarvajñātṛ tvam ca
translated: The mere knowledge of the difference between the Self and the not-Self is the state of being the controller of all things and the knower of all things...

original: nirdhūtarajastamomalasya buddhisattvasya pare vaiśāradye parasyāṃ vaśīkārasaṃjñāyāṃ
analyzed: nirdhūta rajaḥ tamaḥ malasya buddhi sattvasya pare vaiśāradye parasyām vaśīkāra saṃjñāyām
translated: For one whose mind-stuff has shaken off the impurities of rajas and tamas, and who is engaged in the highest fearlessness, in the highest state of mastery called vashikara,

original: vartamānasya sattvapuruṣānyatākhyātimātrarūpapratiṣṭhasya sarvabhāvādhiṣṭhātṛtvam /
analyzed: vartamānasya sattva puruṣa anya tā khyāti mātra rūpa pratiṣṭhasya sarva bhāva adhiṣṭhātṛ tvam
translated: who is established in the form of mere knowledge of the difference between the Self and the not-Self, there is the state of being the controller of all things.

original: sarvātmāno guṇā vyavasāyavyavaseyātmakāḥ svāminaṃ kṣetrajñaṃ pratyaśeṣadṛśyātmatvenopasthitā
analyzed: sarva ātmānaḥ guṇāḥ vyavasāya vyavaseya ātmakāḥ svāminam kṣetrajñam prati aśeṣa dṛśya ātma tvena upasthitā
translated: The qualities, which are the souls of all, being of the nature of the deter-miner and the determined, present themselves to the master, the knower of the field, as the souls of all the objects of perception.

original: ity arthaḥ / sarvajñātṛtvaṃ sarvātmanāṃ guṇānāṃ
analyzed: iti arthaḥ sarva jñātṛ tvam sarva ātmanām guṇānām
translated: This is the meaning. The state of being the knower of all is of the qualities, which are the souls of all,

original: śāntoditāvyapadeśyadharmatvena vyavasthitānām akramopārūḍhaṃ vivekajaṃ jñānam ity
analyzed: śānta udita avyapadeśya dharma tvena vyavasthitānām akrama upārūḍham viveka jam jñānam iti
translated: which are established as having the nature of peace, activity, and the indescribable, and which are beyond time, is the knowledge born of discrimination.

original: arthaḥ / ity eṣā viśokā nāma siddhir yāṃ prāpya yogī sarvajñaḥ kṣīṇakleśabandhano vaśī viharati / /
analyzed: arthaḥ iti eṣā viśokā nāma siddhiḥ yām prāpya yogī sarvajñaḥ kṣīṇa kleśa bandhanaḥ vaśī viharati
translated: This is the meaning. Thus, this is the accomplishment called free from sorrow, having attained which the yogi becomes omniscient, with the bonds of afflictions destroyed, and dwells as a master.

original: tadvairāgyād api doṣabījakṣaye kaivalyam // / //🔽yadāsyaivaṃ bhavati kleśakarmakṣaye sattvasyāyaṃ vivekapratyayo dharmaḥ sattvaṃ ca
analyzed: tad vairāgyāt api doṣa bīja kṣaye kaivalyam  yadā asya evam bhavati kleśa karma kṣaye sattvasya ayam viveka pratyayaḥ dharmaḥ sattvam ca
translated: And by detachment from that, there is liberation upon the destruction of the seeds of faults.

original: heyapakṣe nyastaṃ puruṣaś cāpariṇāmī śuddho 'nyaḥ sattvād iti / evam asya tato virajyamānasya
analyzed: heya pakṣe nyastam puruṣaḥ ca apariṇāmī śuddhaḥ sattvāt iti evam asya tatas virajyamānasya
translated: When he thinks thus: This dharma of discrimination of the sattva is for the destruction of afflictions and actions, and the sattva is placed in the category of what is to be abandoned, and the purusha is changeless, pure, and different from the sattva, then, as he becomes detached from that,

original: yāni kleśabījāni dagdhaśālibījakalpāny aprasavasamarthāni tāni saha manasā pratyastaṃ
analyzed: yāni kleśa bījāni dagdha śāli bīja kalpāni a prasava samarthāni tāni saha manasā pratyastam
translated: the seeds of afflictions, which are like burnt rice seeds, incapable of sprouting, along with the mind, are completely destroyed.

original: gacchanti / teṣu pralīneṣu puruṣaḥ punar idaṃ tāpatrayaṃ na bhuṅkte / tad eteṣāṃ guṇānāṃ🔽manasi karmakleśavipākasvarūpeṇābhivyaktānāṃ caritārthānāṃ pratiprasave puruṣasyātyantiko
analyzed: gacchanti teṣu pralīneṣu puruṣaḥ punar idam tāpa trayam na bhuṅkte tat eteṣām guṇānām  manasi karma kleśa vipāka sva rūpeṇa abhivyaktānām caritārthānām pratiprasave puruṣasya ātyantikaḥ
translated: When they have dissolved, the soul no longer experiences this threefold misery. Then,

original: guṇaviyogaḥ kaivalyaṃ tadā svarūpapratiṣṭhā citiśaktir eva puruṣa iti / /
analyzed: guṇa viyogaḥ kaivalyam tadā svarūpa pratiṣṭhā citi śaktiḥ eva puruṣaḥ iti
translated: when the functions of these guṇas, which have manifested in the mind in the form of action, afflictions, and results, have ceased, there is absolute separation of the soul from the guṇas, which is liberation. At that time, the soul is the power of consciousness established in its own nature.

original: sthānyupanimantraṇe saṅgasmayākaraṇaṃ punar aniṣṭaprasaṅgāt // / //🔽catvāraḥ khalv amī yoginaḥ prāthamakalpiko madhubhūmikaḥ prajñājyotir atikrāntabhāvanīyaś
analyzed: sthāni upanimantraṇe saṅga smayā akaraṇam punar aniṣṭa prasaṅgāt  catvāraḥ khalu amī yoginaḥ prāthamakalpikaḥ madhu bhūmikaḥ prajñā jyotiḥ atikrānta bhāvanīyaḥ
translated: In the invitation of others, the non-production of attachment and pride is due to the undesirable consequences.

original: ceti / tatrābhyāsī pravṛttamātrajyotiḥ prathamaḥ ṛtaṃbharaprajño dvitīyaḥ bhūtendriyajayī
analyzed: ca iti tatra abhyāsī pravṛttamātrajyotiḥ prathamaḥ ṛtaṃbharaprajñaḥ dvitīyaḥ bhūtendriyajayī
translated: There are four kinds of yogis: one who practices for the first time, one who has attained the stage of honey, one who has the light of wisdom, and one who has transcended meditation. Among them, the one who practices is the first, whose light has just arisen. The one with the wisdom of truth is the second. The one who has conquered the elements and senses

original: tṛtīyaḥ sarveṣu bhāviteṣu bhāvanīyeṣu kṛtarakṣābandhaḥ kartavyasādhanād imān / caturtho
analyzed: tṛtīyaḥ sarveṣu bhāviteṣu bhāvanīyeṣu kṛta rakṣā bandhaḥ kartavya sādhanāt imān
translated: is the third. The one who has done the protection-binding for all the objects of meditation, after having meditated on all the objects of meditation, is the fourth.

original: yas tv atikrāntabhāvanīyas tasya cittapratisarga eko 'rthaḥ saptavidhāsya prāntabhūmiprajñā /
analyzed: yaḥ tu atikrānta bhāvanīyaḥ tasya citta pratisargaḥ ekaḥ rthaḥ saptavidhā asya prānta bhūmi prajñā
translated: But for the one who has transcended meditation, the withdrawal of the mind is one thing, and his wisdom at the end of the seven kinds of stages is another.

original: tatra madhumatīṃ bhūmiṃ sākṣātkurvato brāhmaṇasya sthānino devāḥ sattvaviśuddhim
analyzed: tatra madhumatīm bhūmim sākṣātkurvataḥ brāhmaṇasya sthāninaḥ devāḥ sattva viśuddhim
translated: There, the gods who are established, who directly realize the stage of sweetness, see the purification of beings

original: anupaśyantaḥ sthānair upanimantrayante bho ihāsyatām iha ramyatāṃ kamanīyo 'yaṃ bhogaḥ
analyzed: anupaśyantaḥ sthānaiḥ upanimantrayante bho iha āsyatām iha ramyatām kamanīyaḥ yam bhogaḥ
translated: and invite them with their places, saying, Come here, sir, stay here, enjoy this beautiful pleasure,

analyzed: kamanīyā iyam kanyā rasāyanam idam jarā mṛtyum bādhate vaihāyasam idam yānam amī kalpadrumāḥ
translated: this beautiful maiden, this elixir overcomes old age and death, this is a flying chariot, these are wish-fulfilling trees,

analyzed: puṇyā mandākinī siddhāḥ mahā ṛṣayaḥ uttamāḥ anukūlāḥ apsarasaḥ divye śrotra cakṣuṣī vajra upamaḥ
translated: this is the meritorious Mandakini, these are accomplished great sages, these are the most excellent celestial nymphs, these are divine ears and eyes, this body is like a diamond.

analyzed: kāyaḥ sva guṇaiḥ sarvam idam upārjitam āyuṣmatā pratipadyatām idam akṣayam ajaram
translated: All this has been acquired by you, long-lived one, with your own qualities. Accept this imperishable, ageless

analyzed: amara sthānam devānām priyam iti evam abhidhīyamānaḥ saṅga doṣān bhāvayet ghoreṣu
translated: abode of the immortals, dear to the gods. When addressed thus, he should contemplate the faults of attachment in these terrible

original: saṃsārāṅgāreṣu pacyamānena mayā jananamaraṇāndhakāre viparivartamānena kathaṃcid
analyzed: saṃsāra aṅgāreṣu pacyamānena mayā janana maraṇa andhakāre viparivartamānena kathaṃcid
translated: hells where he is being cooked, and while wandering in the darkness of birth and death, somehow

analyzed: āsāditaḥ kleśa timira vināśī yoga pradīpaḥ tasya ca ete tṛṣṇā yonayaḥ viṣaya vāyavaḥ pratipakṣāḥ
translated: he has obtained the lamp of yoga, which destroys the darkness of afflictions, and these sources of craving, the sense objects, are its antidotes.

analyzed: sa khalu aham labdha ālokaḥ katham anayā viṣaya mṛgatṛṣṇayā vañcitaḥ tasya eva punar
translated: Having obtained light, how can I be deceived by this mirage of objects and again

analyzed: pradīptasya saṃsāra agneḥ ātmānam indhanīkuryām iti svasti vaḥ svapna upamebhyaḥ kṛpaṇa jana prārthanīyebhyaḥ
translated: make myself fuel for that very burning fire of samsara?' Wishing well to you, who are like dreams, who are to be desired by miserly people,

analyzed: viṣayebhyaḥ iti evam niścita matiḥ samādhim bhāvayet  saṅgam a kṛtvā smayam api na kuryāt evam aham devānām api prārthanīyaḥ iti smayāt ayam
translated: to the objects, with this settled mind one should cultivate concentration.

original: susthitaṃmanyatayā mṛtyunā keśeṣu gṛhītam ivātmānaṃ na bhāvayiṣyati / tathā cāsya
analyzed: susthitaṃmanya tayā mṛtyunā keśeṣu gṛhītam iva ātmānam na bhāvayiṣyati tathā ca asya
translated: Not having attachment, one should not even smile, thinking 'I am to be desired even by the gods.' From pride, he will not cultivate himself as if grasped by death by the hair with the thought 'I am well-established.' And thus

original: cchidrāntaraprekṣī nityaṃ yatnopacaryaḥ pramādo labdhavivaraḥ kleśān uttambhayiṣyati
analyzed: chidra antara prekṣī nityam yatna upacaryaḥ pramādaḥ labdha vivaraḥ kleśān uttambhayiṣyati
translated: he will always be watched for a weak spot, and carelessness, which is to be attended to with effort, having obtained an opportunity, will exalt the afflictions.

original: tataḥ punar aniṣṭaprasaṅgaḥ / evam asya saṅgasmayāv akurvato bhāvito 'rtho dṛḍhībhaviṣyati
analyzed: tatas punar aniṣṭa prasaṅgaḥ evam asya saṅga smayau akurvataḥ bhāvitaḥ rthaḥ dṛḍhībhaviṣyati
translated: Then again there will be the occurrence of the undesirable. Thus, for him who does not have attachment and pride, the cultivated meaning will become firm

original: bhāvanīyaś cārtho 'bhimukhībhaviṣyatīti / /
analyzed: bhāvanīyaḥ ca arthaḥ bhimukhībhaviṣyati iti

original: kṣaṇatatkramayoḥ saṃyamād vivekajaṃ jñānam // / //
translated: From the restraint of the moment and its sequence, knowledge born of discrimination...🔽...

original: yathāpakarṣaparyantaṃ dravyaṃ paramāṇur evaṃ paramāpakarṣaparyantaḥ kālaḥ kṣaṇo yāvatā
analyzed: yathā apakarṣa paryantam dravyam paramāṇuḥ evam parama apakarṣa paryantaḥ kālaḥ kṣaṇaḥ yāvatā
translated: Just as substance has the ultimate smallest unit, the atom, so time has the ultimate smallest unit, the moment, which is the time

original: vā samayena calitaḥ paramāṇuḥ pūrvadeśaṃ jahyād uttaradeśam upasaṃpadyeta sa kālaḥ
analyzed: vā samayena calitaḥ paramāṇuḥ pūrva deśam jahyāt uttara deśam upasaṃpadyeta sa kālaḥ
translated: in which an atom, moving at the speed of an arrow, would traverse the distance of one atom.

original: kṣaṇaḥ / tatpravāhāvicchedas tu kramaḥ kṣaṇatatkramayor nāsti vastusamāhāra iti buddhisamāhāro🔽muhūrtāhorātrādayaḥ / sa khalv ayaṃ kālo vastuśūnyo 'pi buddhinirmāṇaḥ śabdajñānānupātī
analyzed: kṣaṇaḥ tad pravāha avicchedaḥ tu kramaḥ kṣaṇa tad kramayoḥ na asti vastu samāhāraḥ iti  muhūrta ahar rātra ādayaḥ sa khalu ayam kālaḥ buddhi nirmāṇaḥ śabda jñāna anupātī
translated: That is a moment. But a series is a continuity of those [moments]. A collection of entities does not exist in a series or a moment, so a collection of cognitions

original: laukikānāṃ vyutthitadarśanānāṃ vastusvarūpa ivāvabhāsate /
analyzed: laukikānām vyutthita darśanānām vastu svarūpe iva avabhāsate
translated: is a muhurta, a day and night, etc. That time, although empty of substance, appears to worldly people who are not followers of the Buddha's teachings as if it were the nature of a substance, like a creation of the mind.

original: kṣaṇas tu vastupatitaḥ kramāvalambī kramaś ca kṣaṇānantaryātmā taṃ kālavidaḥ kāla
analyzed: kṣaṇaḥ tu vastu patitaḥ krama avalambī kramaḥ ca kṣaṇa ānantarya ātmā tam kāla vidaḥ kāla
translated: But a moment is included in a substance, and a series is based on a moment. And the yogis who know time call that series, which is the immediate succession of moments,

original: ity ācakṣate yoginaḥ / na ca dvau kṣaṇau saha bhavataḥ kramaś ca na dvayoḥ sahabhuvor
analyzed: iti ācakṣate yoginaḥ na ca dvau kṣaṇau saha bhavataḥ kramaḥ ca na dvayoḥ saha bhuvoḥ
translated: time. And two moments do not exist together, and there is no series of two co-existent [moments],

original: asaṃbhavāt / pūrvasmād uttarabhāvino yadānantaryaṃ kṣaṇasya sa kramaḥ tasmād vartamāna
analyzed: asaṃbhavāt pūrvasmāt uttara bhāvinaḥ yat ānantaryam kṣaṇasya sa kramaḥ tasmāt vartamāna
translated: because it is impossible. When there is immediate succession of a moment after the previous one, that is a series. Therefore, the present

original: evaikaḥ kṣaṇo na pūrvottarakṣaṇāḥ santīti / tasmān nāsti tatsamāhāraḥ ye tu bhūtabhāvinaḥ
analyzed: eva ekaḥ kṣaṇaḥ na pūrva uttara kṣaṇāḥ santi iti tasmāt na asti tad samāhāraḥ ye tu bhūta bhāvinaḥ
translated: Thus, there is only one moment, and there are no prior or subsequent moments. Therefore, there is no collection of them. But those moments that are past and future

original: kṣaṇās te pariṇāmānvitā vyākhyeyāḥ tenaikena kṣaṇena kṛtsno lokaḥ pariṇāmam anubhavati /
analyzed: kṣaṇāḥ te pariṇāma anvitāḥ vyākhyeyāḥ tena ekena kṣaṇena kṛtsnaḥ lokaḥ pariṇāmam anubhavati
translated: should be explained as having transformation. By that single moment, the entire world experiences transformation.

original: tatkṣaṇopārūḍhāḥ khalv amī sarve dharmāḥ tayoḥ kṣaṇatatkramayoḥ saṃyamāt tayoḥ sākṣātkaraṇam /
analyzed: tad kṣaṇa upārūḍhāḥ khalu amī sarve dharmāḥ tayoḥ kṣaṇa tad kramayoḥ saṃyamāt tayoḥ sākṣātkaraṇam
translated: Indeed, all these dharmas are included in that moment. By the restraint of those two, the moment and its sequence, there is direct realization of them.

original: tataś ca vivekajaṃ jñānaṃ prādurbhavati / /
analyzed: tatas ca viveka jam jñānam prādurbhavati
translated: And from that, knowledge born of discrimination arises.

original: tasya viṣayaviśeṣa upakṣipyate 🔽jātilakṣaṇadeśair anyatānavacchedāt tulyayos tataḥ pratipattiḥ // / //
analyzed: tasya viṣaya viśeṣaḥ upakṣipyate  jāti lakṣaṇa deśaiḥ anyatā anavacchedāt tulyayoḥ tatas pratipattiḥ
translated: The specific object of that [knowledge] is introduced:🔽Because difference is not determined by genus, characteristics, or place, there is understanding of the two as the same...

original: tulyayor deśalakṣaṇasārūpye jātibhedo 'nyatāyā hetuḥ /
analyzed: tulyayoḥ deśa lakṣaṇa sārūpye jāti bhedaḥ nya tāyāḥ hetuḥ
translated: When the two are similar in place and characteristics, the difference in genus is the cause of difference.

original: gaur iyaṃ baḍaveyam iti / tulyadeśajātīyatve lakṣaṇam anyatvakaraṃ kālākṣī gauḥ svastimatī
analyzed: gauḥ iyam baḍavā iyam iti tulya deśa jātīya tve lakṣaṇam anyatva karam kāla akṣī gauḥ svastimatī
translated: This is a cow, this is a horse. When the two are similar in place and genus, the characteristic is the cause of difference. The black-eyed cow, the prosperous cow,

original: gaur iti / dvayor āmalakayor jātilakṣaṇasārūpyād deśabhedo 'nyatvakara idaṃ pūrvam
analyzed: gauḥ iti dvayoḥ āmalakayoḥ jāti lakṣaṇa sārūpyāt deśa bhedaḥ nyatva karaḥ idam pūrvam
translated: the cow. When the two are similar in genus and characteristics, the difference in place is the cause of difference. This is the eastern,🔽this is the western.

original: idam uttaram iti / yadā tu pūrvam āmalakam anyavyagrasya jñātur uttaradeśa upāvartyate
analyzed: idam uttaram iti yadā tu pūrvam āmalakam anya vyagrasya jñātuḥ uttara deśe upāvartyate
translated: This is the reply. But when the previous myrobalan is placed in a different place by a distracted cognizer,

original: tadā tulyadeśatve pūrvam etad uttaram etad iti pravibhāgānupapattiḥ / asaṃdigdhena
analyzed: tadā tulya deśa tve pūrvam etat uttaram etat iti pravibhāga anupapattiḥ asaṃdigdhena
translated: then, when they have the same place, it is not possible to distinguish this is the previous one and this is the later one. And one should have knowledge of reality without doubt.

original: ca tattvajñānena bhavitavyam ity ata idam uktaṃ tataḥ pratipattir vivekajajñānād iti /
analyzed: ca tattva jñānena bhavitavyam iti atas idam uktam tatas pratipattiḥ viveka ja jñānāt iti
translated: Therefore, this is said: The realization comes from the knowledge born of discrimination.

original: kathaṃ / pūrvāmalakasahakṣaṇo deśa uttarāmalakasahakṣaṇād deśād bhinnaḥ te cāmalake
analyzed: katham pūrva āmalaka sahakṣaṇaḥ deśaḥ uttara āmalaka sahakṣaṇāt deśāt bhinnaḥ te ca āmalake
translated: How? The place that is simultaneous with the previous myrobalan is different from the place simultaneous with the later myrobalan. And those myrobalans

original: svadeśakṣaṇānubhavabhinne / anyadeśakṣaṇānubhavas tu tayor anyatve hetur iti / etena
analyzed: sva deśa kṣaṇa anubhava bhinne anya deśa kṣaṇa anubhavaḥ tu tayoḥ anya tve hetuḥ iti etena
translated: are different in the experience of their own places and moments. But the experience of other places and moments is the cause of their difference. By this

original: dṛṣṭāntena paramāṇos tulyajātilakṣaṇadeśasya pūrvaparamāṇudeśasahakṣaṇasākṣātkaraṇād
analyzed: dṛṣṭāntena paramāṇoḥ tulya jāti lakṣaṇa deśasya pūrva paramāṇu deśa sahakṣaṇa sākṣātkaraṇāt
translated: example, the place characterized by the same class and characteristics of the atom is directly perceived simultaneously with the place of the previous atom.

original: uttarasya paramāṇos taddeśānupapattāv uttarasya taddeśānubhavo bhinnaḥ sahakṣaṇabhedāt
analyzed: uttarasya paramāṇoḥ tad deśa anupapattau uttarasya tad deśa anubhavaḥ bhinnaḥ saha kṣaṇa bhedāt
translated: Due to the non-occurrence of the later atom in that place, the experience of that place of the later one is different due to the difference in simultaneity.

original: tayor īśvarasya yogino 'nyatvapratyayo bhavatīti /
analyzed: tayoḥ īśvarasya yoginaḥ nya tva pratyayaḥ bhavati iti
translated: The cognition of difference of the two belongs to God, the yogi.

original: apare tu varṇayanti ye 'ntyā viśeṣās te 'nyatāpratyayaṃ kurvantīti tatrāpi deśalakṣaṇabhedo
analyzed: apare tu varṇayanti ye ntyāḥ viśeṣāḥ te nyatā pratyayam kurvanti iti tatra api deśa lakṣaṇa bhedaḥ
translated: But others explain: Those ultimate specificities cause the cognition of difference. Even there, the difference of place and characteristics,

original: mūrtivyavadhijātibhedaś cānyatve hetuḥ / kṣaṇabhedas tu yogibuddhigamya eveti ata
analyzed: mūrti vyavadhi jāti bhedaḥ ca anyatve hetuḥ kṣaṇa bhedaḥ tu yogi buddhi gamyaḥ evā iti atas
translated: and the difference of form, obstruction, and class are the causes of difference. But the difference of moments is only to be understood by the mind of a yogi. Therefore,

original: uktaṃ mūrtivyavadhijātibhedābhāvān nāsti mūlapṛthaktvam iti vārṣagaṇyaḥ / /
analyzed: uktam mūrti vyavadhi jāti bheda abhāvāt na asti mūla pṛthaktvam iti vārṣagaṇyaḥ
translated: it is said: Because there is no difference of form, obstruction, and class, there is no difference of root, according to Vārṣagaṇya.

original: tārakaṃ sarvaviṣayaṃ sarvathāviṣayam akramaṃ ceti vivekajaṃ jñānam // / //
analyzed: tārakam sarva viṣayam sarvathāviṣayam akramam ca iti viveka jam jñānam
translated: The knowledge born of discrimination is illuminating, having all things as its object, having all modes of things as its object, and is without sequence.

original: tārakam iti svapratibhottham anaupadeśikam ity arthaḥ sarvaviṣayaṃ nāsya kiṃcid aviṣayībhūtam
analyzed: tārakam iti sva pratibhā uttham anaupadeśikam iti arthaḥ sarva viṣayam na asya kiṃcid aviṣayībhūtam
translated: Illuminating means arising from one's own insight, not taught by others, is the meaning. Having all things as its object means there is nothing that is not its object.

original: ity arthaḥ / sarvathāviṣayam atītānāgatapratyutpannaṃ sarvaṃ paryāyaiḥ sarvathā jānātīty
analyzed: iti arthaḥ sarvathā viṣayam atīta anāgata pratyutpannam sarvam paryāyaiḥ sarvathā jānāti iti
translated: This is the meaning. Having all modes of things as its object means it knows all past, future, and present things in all modes through synonyms.

original: arthaḥ / akramam ity ekakṣaṇopārūḍhaṃ sarvaṃ sarvathā gṛhṇātīty arthaḥ / etad vivekajaṃ
analyzed: arthaḥ akramam iti eka kṣaṇa upārūḍham sarvam sarvathā gṛhṇāti iti arthaḥ etat viveka jam
translated: This is the meaning. Without sequence means it grasps all things in all modes in a single moment, this is the meaning. This knowledge born of discrimination,

original: jñānaṃ paripūrṇam asyaivāṃśo yogapradīpo madhumatīṃ bhūmim upādāya yāvad asya parisamāptir iti / /
analyzed: jñānam paripūrṇam asya eva aṃśaḥ yoga pradīpaḥ madhumatīm bhūmim upādāya yāvat asya parisamāptiḥ iti
translated: being complete, is a part of it. The lamp of yoga, beginning from the stage of sweetness up to its completion, is like this.

original: prāptavivekajajñānasyāprāptavivekajajñānasya vā
analyzed: prāpta viveka ja jñānasya aprāpta viveka ja jñānasya vā
translated: for one who has attained knowledge born of discrimination or for one who has not attained it,

original: sattvapuruṣayoḥ śuddhisāmye kaivalyam iti // / //
analyzed: sattva puruṣayoḥ śuddhi sāmye kaivalyam iti
translated: When there is equality of purification of the soul and the spirit, there is liberation, for one who has attained the knowledge born of discrimination or for one who has not attained it.

original: yadā nirdhūtarajastamomalaṃ buddhisattvaṃ puruṣasyānyatāpratītimātrādhikāraṃ dagdhakleśabījaṃ bhavati tadā puruṣasya śuddhisārūpyam ivāpannaṃ
analyzed: yadā nirdhūta rajaḥ tamaḥ malam buddhi sattvam puruṣasya anyatā pratīti mātra adhikāram dagdha kleśa bījam bhavati tadā puruṣasya śuddhi sārūpyam iva āpannam
translated: When the intellect-substance has shaken off the impurities of passion and darkness, and is fit only for the perception of the difference between the Spirit and itself, and the seeds of the afflictions are burnt, then the Spirit attains as it were the purity and identity of form with the intellect.

original: tadā puruṣasyopacaritabhogābhāvaḥ śuddhiḥ / etasyām avasthāyāṃ kaivalyaṃ bhavatīśvarasyānīśvarasya
analyzed: tadā puruṣasya upacarita bhoga abhāvaḥ śuddhiḥ etasyām avasthāyām kaivalyam bhavati īśvarasya anīśvarasya
translated: Then the purification of the Spirit is the absence of the enjoyment that is superimposed on it. In this state, there is liberation for the Spirit, whether it is the Lord or the non-Lord,

original: vā vivekajajñānabhāgina itarasya vā / na hi dagdhakleśabījasya jñāne punar apekṣā
analyzed: vā viveka ja jñāna bhāginaḥ itarasya vā na hi dagdha kleśa bījasya jñāne punar apekṣā
translated: or for one who has a share in the knowledge born of discrimination, or for another. For one whose seeds of afflictions are burnt, there is no further need for knowledge.

original: kācid asti sattvaśuddhidvāreṇaitat samādhijam aiśvaryaṃ jñānaṃ copakrāntam / paramārthatas
analyzed: kācid asti sattva śuddhi dvāreṇa etat samādhi jam aiśvaryam jñānam ca upakrāntam paramārthatas
translated: This lordship and knowledge born of concentration are begun by way of the purification of the intellect. But in reality,

original: tu jñānād adarśanaṃ nivartate tasmin nivṛtte na santy uttare kleśāḥ / kleśābhāvāt
analyzed: tu jñānāt adarśanam nivartate tasmin nivṛtte na santi uttare kleśāḥ kleśa abhāvāt
translated: ignorance ceases due to knowledge. When that ceases, there are no further afflictions. Due to the absence of afflictions,

original: karmavipākābhāvaḥ caritādhikārāś caitasyām avasthāyāṃ guṇā na puruṣasya punar dṛśyatvenopatiṣṭhante /
analyzed: karma vipāka abhāvaḥ carita adhikārāḥ ca etasyām avasthāyām guṇāḥ na puruṣasya punar dṛśya tvena upatiṣṭhante
translated: there is the absence of the fruition of actions. And in this state, the constituents, having fulfilled their purpose, do not present themselves to the Spirit again as objects of perception.

original: tatpuruṣasya kaivalyaṃ /
analyzed: tatpuruṣasya kaivalyam
translated: The liberation of the Purusha.

original: tadā puruṣaḥ svarūpamātrajyotir amalaḥ kevalī bhavati / /
analyzed: tadā puruṣaḥ sva rūpa mātra jyotiḥ amalaḥ kevalī bhavati
translated: Then the Purusha becomes pure, enlightened with its own nature alone, and liberated.

original: iti śrīpātañjale sāṃkhyapravacane yogaśāstre vyāsabhāṣye vibhūtipādas tṛtīyaḥ /
analyzed: iti śrī pātañjale sāṃkhyapravacane yogaśāstre vyāsa bhāṣye vibhūti pādaḥ tṛtīyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the third chapter named Vibhuti Pada in the Yoga Shastra commentary by Vyasa on the Patanjali Shastra of Samkhya.

original: janmauṣadhimantratapaḥsamādhijāḥ siddhayaḥ // / //
analyzed: janma auṣadhi mantra tapaḥ samādhi jāḥ siddhayaḥ
translated: The accomplishments born of birth, herbs, mantras, austerities, and samadhi.

original: dehāntaritā janmanā siddhiḥ oṣadhibhir asurabhavaneṣu rasāyanenety evamādiḥ / mantrair ākāśagamanāṇimādilābhaḥ / tapasā saṃkalpasiddhiḥ /
analyzed: deha antaritā janmanā siddhiḥ oṣadhibhiḥ asura bhavaneṣu rasāyanena iti evamādiḥ mantraiḥ ākāśa gamana aṇima ādi lābhaḥ tapasā saṃkalpa siddhiḥ
translated: The accomplishment through birth is the attainment of another body. The accomplishment through herbs is the elixir in the abodes of the asuras and so on. The accomplishment through mantras is the attainment of the ability to fly in the sky and other powers. The accomplishment through austerities is the fulfillment of desires.

original: kāmarūpī yatra tatra kāmaga ity evamādi samādhijāḥ siddhayo vyākhyātāḥ / /
analyzed: kāmarūpī yatra tatra kāma gaḥ iti evamādi samādhi jāḥ siddhayaḥ vyākhyātāḥ
translated: The accomplishments through samadhi are described as the ability to assume any form one desires, to go anywhere one wishes, and so on.

original: tatra kāyendriyāṇām anyajātīyapariṇatānām
analyzed: tatra kāya indriyāṇām anya jātīya pariṇatānām
translated: Among them, the bodily organs that have transformed into different species,

original: jātyantarapariṇāmaḥ prakṛtyāpūrāt // / //
analyzed: jāti antara pariṇāmaḥ prakṛti āpūrāt
translated: The transformation into another species is due to the filling up of prakriti.

original: pūrvapariṇāmāpāya uttarapariṇāmopajanas teṣām apūrvāvayavānupraveśād bhavati / kāyendriyaprakṛtayaś ca svaṃ svaṃ vikāram anugṛhṇanty āpūreṇa
analyzed: pūrva pariṇāma apāye uttara pariṇāma upajanaḥ teṣām apūrva avayava anupraveśāt bhavati kāya indriya prakṛtayaḥ ca svam svam vikāram anugṛhṇanti āpūreṇa
translated: The disappearance of the previous transformation and the appearance of the subsequent transformation occur due to the entry of new parts, and the prakritis of the bodily organs support their own modifications through filling up,

original: dharmādinimittam apekṣamāṇā iti / /
analyzed: dharma ādi nimittam apekṣamāṇāḥ iti
translated: While depending on dharma and other causes.

original: nimittam aprayojakaṃ prakṛtīnāṃ varaṇabhedas tu tataḥ kṣetrikavat // / //
analyzed: nimittam aprayojakam prakṛtīnām varaṇa bhedaḥ tu tatas kṣetrika vat
translated: The cause is not the motive for the modifications of the primordial material substances, but the distinction of coverings is from that, like the owner of the field.

original: na hi dharmādi nimittaṃ tatprayojakaṃ prakṛtīnāṃ bhavati na kāryeṇa kāraṇaṃ pravartyata iti kathaṃ tarhi /
analyzed: na hi dharma ādi nimittam tad prayojakam prakṛtīnām bhavati na kāryeṇa kāraṇam pravartyate iti katham tarhi
translated: For dharma etc. is not the cause, the motive for the modifications of the primordial material substances. A cause is not set in motion by an effect. How then?

original: varaṇabhedas tu tataḥ kṣetrikavat / yathā kṣetrikaḥ kedārād apāṃ pūrṇāt kedārāntaraṃ
analyzed: varaṇa bhedaḥ tu tatas kṣetrika vat yathā kṣetrikaḥ kedārāt apām pūrṇāt kedāra antaram
translated: But the distinction of coverings is from that, like the owner of the field. Just as the owner of a field, wishing to flood another field from a field full of water,

original: piplāvayiṣuḥ samaṃ nimnaṃ nimnataraṃ vā nāpaḥ pāṇināpakarṣaty āvaraṇaṃ tv āsāṃ bhinatti🔽tasmin bhinne svayam evāpaḥ kedārāntaram āplāvayanti tathā dharmaḥ prakṛtīnām āvaraṇadharmaṃ
analyzed: piplāvayiṣuḥ samam nimnam nimnataram vā na apaḥ pāṇinā apakarṣati āvaraṇam tu āsām bhinatti  tasmin bhinne svayam eva apaḥ kedāra antaram āplāvayanti tathā dharmaḥ prakṛtīnām āvaraṇa dharmam
translated: does not draw out the water with his hand from the lower, lower, or even level field, but breaks its covering,🔽when that is broken, the water itself floods the other field. In the same way, dharma breaks the covering dharma of the primordial material substances.

original: bhinatti tasmin bhinne svayam eva prakṛtayaḥ svaṃ svaṃ vikāram āplāvayanti / yathā
analyzed: bhinatti tasmin bhinne svayam eva prakṛtayaḥ svam svam vikāram āplāvayanti yathā
translated: When that is broken, the primordial material substances themselves flood their own modifications. Just as

original: vā sa eva kṣetrikas tasminn eva kedāre na prabhavaty audakān bhaumān vā rasān dhānyamūlāny anupraveśayituṃ /
analyzed: vā saḥ eva kṣetrikaḥ tasmin eva kedāre na prabhavati audakān bhaumān vā rasān dhānya mūlāni anupraveśayitum
translated: or that same owner of the field is not able to introduce the watery or earthly juices into the roots of the grain in that same field.

original: kiṃ tarhi mudgagavedhukaśyāmākādīṃs tato 'pakarṣati / apakṛṣṭeṣu teṣu svayam eva rasā dhānyamūlāny anupraviśanti /
analyzed: kim tarhi mudga gavedhuka śyāmāka ādīn upakarṣati apakṛṣṭeṣu teṣu svayam eva rasāḥ dhānya mūlāni anupraviśanti
translated: What then? He removes the mudga, gavedhuka, shyamaka, etc. from it. When they are removed, the juices enter the roots of the grains by themselves.

original: tathā dharmo nivṛttimātre kāraṇam adharmasya /
analyzed: tathā dharmaḥ nivṛtti mātre kāraṇam adharmasya
translated: Similarly, dharma is the cause of mere cessation of adharma.

original: śuddhyaśuddhyor atyantavirodhāt /
analyzed: śuddhi aśuddhyoḥ atyanta virodhāt
translated: Because purity and impurity are in complete opposition.

original: na tu prakṛtipravṛttau dharmo hetur bhavatīti / atra nandīśvarādaya udāhāryāḥ viparyayeṇāpy
analyzed: na tu prakṛti pravṛttau dharmaḥ hetuḥ bhavati iti atra nandīśvara ādayaḥ udāhāryāḥ viparyayeṇa api
translated: But dharma is not a cause for the natural activity [of adharma]. Here, Nandisvara and others should be cited. Even by the opposite,

original: adharmo dharmaṃ bādhate / tataś cāśuddhipariṇāma iti / tatrāpi nahuṣājagarādaya udāhāryāḥ / /
analyzed: adharmaḥ dharmam bādhate tatas ca aśuddhi pariṇāmaḥ iti tatra api nahuṣa ajagara ādayaḥ udāhāryāḥ
translated: adharma obstructs dharma. And from that, there is the transformation of impurity. There also, Nahusha, Ajagara, and others should be cited.🔽But when a yogi creates many bodies, then do they have one mind or many minds?

original: yadā tu yogī bahūn kāyān nirmimīte tadā kim ekamanaskās te bhavanty athānekamanaskā iti 🔽nirmāṇacittāny asmitāmātrāt // / //
analyzed: yadā tu yogī bahūn kāyān nirmimīte tadā kim eka manaskāḥ te bhavanti atha aneka manaskāḥ iti  nirmāṇa cittāni asmitā mātrāt
translated: The creation minds are from mere I-am-ness.

original: asmitāmātraṃ cittakāraṇam upādāya nirmāṇacittāni karoti /
analyzed: asmitā mātram citta kāraṇam upādāya nirmāṇa cittāni karoti
translated: Taking mere I-am-ness, which is the cause of mind, as the basis, he creates the creation minds.

original: tataḥ sacittāni bhavantīti / /
analyzed: tatas sa cittāni bhavanti iti
translated: Therefore, they have minds.

original: pravṛttibhede prayojakaṃ cittam ekam anekeṣām // / //
analyzed: pravṛtti bhede prayojakam cittam ekam anekeṣām
translated: When there is a difference in activity, the mind is one for many.🔽...

original: bahūnāṃ cittānāṃ katham ekacittābhiprāyapuraḥsarā pravṛttir iti sarvacittānāṃ prayojakaṃ cittam ekaṇ nirmimīte /
analyzed: bahūnām cittānām katham eka citta abhiprāya puraḥsarā pravṛttiḥ iti sarva cittānām prayojakam cittam nirmimīte
translated: How can there be an engagement with a single intention of mind for many minds? He creates a single mind that is the instigator of all minds.

original: tataḥ pravṛttibhedaḥ / /
analyzed: tatas pravṛtti bhedaḥ
translated: Then there is a difference in engagement.

original: tatra dhyānajam anāśayam // / //
analyzed: tatra dhyāna jam anāśayam
translated: There, the one born of meditation is without intention...

original: pañcavidhaṃ nirmāṇacittaṃ janmauṣadhimantratapaḥsamādhijāḥ siddhaya iti / tatra yad
analyzed: pañcavidham nirmāṇa cittam janma auṣadhi mantra tapaḥ samādhi jāḥ siddhayaḥ iti tatra yat
translated: The mind of emanation is of five kinds: those born of birth, herbs, mantras, austerities, and concentration. Among them,

original: eva dhyānajaṃ cittaṃ tad evānāśayaṃ tasyaiva nāsty āśayo rāgādipravṛttir nātaḥ puṇyapāpābhisaṃbandhaḥ
analyzed: eva dhyāna jam cittam tat eva anāśayam tasya eva na asti āśayaḥ rāga ādi pravṛttiḥ na atas puṇya pāpa abhisaṃbandhaḥ
translated: that very mind born of meditation is without intention. For that very [mind], there is no intention, no engagement in passion etc. Therefore, there is no connection with merit and demerit.

original: kṣīṇakleśatvād yogina iti itareṣāṃ tu vidyate karmāśayaḥ / /
analyzed: kṣīṇa kleśa tvāt yoginaḥ iti itareṣām tu vidyate karma āśayaḥ
translated: Because the yogi has exhausted the defilements. But for the others, there is a store of karma.

original: yataḥ
analyzed: yatas
translated: From which:

original: karmāśuklākṛṣṇaṃ yoginas trividham itareṣām // / //
analyzed: karma a śukla a kṛṣṇam yoginaḥ trividham itareṣām
translated: The karma of the yogi is threefold, not white and not black, but that of others is...

original: catuṣpadī khalv iyaṃ karmajātiḥ kṛṣṇā śuklakṛṣṇā śuklāśuklākṛṣṇā ceti / tatra kṛṣṇā durātmanām /
analyzed: catuṣpadī khalu iyam karma jātiḥ kṛṣṇā śukla kṛṣṇā śukla a śukla a kṛṣṇā ca iti tatra kṛṣṇā durātmanām
translated: This class of karma is indeed fourfold: black, white-black, white, and neither white nor black. Among them, the black [karma] is of the wicked.

original: śuklakṛṣṇā bahiḥsādhanasādhyā / tatra parapīḍānugrahadvāreṇaiva karmāśayapracayaḥ
analyzed: śukla kṛṣṇā bahis sādhana sādhyā tatra para pīḍā anugraha dvāreṇa eva karma āśaya pracayaḥ
translated: The white-black [karma] is accomplished by external means. There, the accumulation of the store of karma is only through the door of harming and benefiting others.

original: śuklā tapaḥsvādhyāyadhyānavatām / sā hi kevale manasy āyattatvād abahiḥsādhanādhīnā
analyzed: śuklā tapaḥ svādhyāya dhyānavatām sā hi kevale manasi āyatta tvāt a bahis sādhana adhīnā
translated: The white one is for those who are engaged in austerity, self-study, and meditation. For that [action] depends solely on the mind and is not subject to external means,

original: na parān pīḍayitvā bhavati / aśuklākṛṣṇā saṃnyāsināṃ kṣīṇakleśānāṃ caramadehānām iti🔽tatrāśuklaṃ yogina eva phalasaṃnyāsād akṛṣṇaṃ cānupādānāt itareṣāṃ tu bhūtānāṃ pūrvam
analyzed: na parān pīḍayitvā bhavati a śukla a kṛṣṇā saṃnyāsinām kṣīṇa kleśānām carama dehānām iti  tatra aśuklam yoginaḥ eva phala saṃnyāsāt akṛṣṇam ca anupādānāt itareṣām tu bhūtānām pūrvam
translated: and does not come about by harming others. The neither-white-nor-black one is for ascetics who have exhausted the afflictions and have their last bodies.🔽Among them, the neither-white nor black one is for yogis because they renounce the fruits [of action], and it is not black because they do not accumulate [karmic fruits]. But for other beings, it is threefold

original: eva trividham iti / /
analyzed: eva trividham iti
translated: from the very beginning.

original: tatas tadvipākānuguṇānām evābhivyaktir vāsanānām // / //
analyzed: tatas tad vipāka anuguṇānām evā abhivyaktiḥ vāsanānām
translated: Then, only those latent impressions that are in accordance with its ripening become manifest.

original: tata iti trividhāt karmaṇaḥ /
analyzed: tatas iti trividhāt karmaṇaḥ
translated: Then means from the threefold action.

original: tadvipākānuguṇānām eveti yajjātīyasya karmaṇo yo vipākas tasyānuguṇā yā vāsanāḥ karmavipākam
analyzed: tad vipāka anuguṇānām eva iti yad jātīyasya karmaṇaḥ yaḥ vipākaḥ tasya anuguṇāḥ yāḥ vāsanāḥ karma vipākam
translated: Only those that are in accordance with its ripening means that the latent impressions that follow the ripening of that type of action,

original: anuśerate tāsām evābhivyaktiḥ / na hi daivaṃ karma vipacyamānaṃ nārakatiryaṅmanuṣyavāsanābhivyaktinimittaṃ
analyzed: anuśerate tāsām eva abhivyaktiḥ na hi daivam karma vipacyamānam nāraka tiryak manuṣya vāsanā abhivyakti nimittam
translated: only those become manifest. For when divine action ripens, it cannot be the cause for the manifestation of latent impressions in hell, animal, or human [realms],

original: saṃbhavati kiṃtu daivānuguṇā evāsya vāsanā vyajyante nārakatiryaṅmanuṣyeṣu caivaṃ samānaś carcaḥ / /
analyzed: saṃbhavati kiṃtu daiva anuguṇāḥ eva asya vāsanāḥ vyajyante nāraka tiryak manuṣyeṣu ca evam samānaḥ carcaḥ
translated: but only those latent impressions that are in accordance with the divine [realm] become manifest. And the same discussion applies to hell, animal, and human [realms].

original: jātideśakālavyavahitānām apy ānantaryaṃ smṛtisaṃskārayor ekarūpatvāt // / //
analyzed: jāti deśa kāla vyavahitānām api ānantaryam smṛti saṃskārayoḥ eka rūpa tvāt
translated: Even when separated by birth, place, and time, there is immediate succession, because memory and impressions have the same form.

original: vṛṣadaṃśavipākodayaḥ svavyañjakāñjanābhivyaktaḥ / sa yadi jātiśatena vā dūradeśatayā
analyzed: vṛṣadaṃśa vipāka udayaḥ sva vyañjaka añjana abhivyaktaḥ sa yadi jāti śatena vā dūra deśa tayā
translated: The ripening of a cat is manifested by its manifesting conditions. If it is separated by a hundred births or by a hundred kalpas due to being in a distant place,

original: vā kalpaśatena vā vyavahitaḥ punaś ca svavyañjakāñjana evodiyād drāg ity evaṃ pūrvānubhūtavṛṣadaṃśavipākābhisaṃskṛtā🔽vāsanā upādāya vyajyeta / kasmāt /
analyzed: vā kalpa śatena vā vyavahitaḥ punar ca sva vyañjaka añjanaḥ evā udiyāt drāk iti evam pūrva anubhūta vṛṣadaṃśa vipāka abhisaṃskṛtā  vāsanā upādāya vyajyeta kasmāt
translated: and then again arises from its own manifesting conditions, it would quickly manifest in this way, based on the impressions created by the previously experienced ripening of a cat. Why is this?

original: yato vyavahitānām apy āsāṃ sadṛśaṃ karmābhivyajñakaṃ nimittībhūtam ity ānantaryam eva / kutaś ca /
analyzed: yatas vyavahitānām api āsām sadṛśam karma abhivyajñakam nimittībhūtam iti ānantaryam eva kutas ca
translated: Because for these [impressions], even when separated, a similar action becomes the manifesting cause, so there is immediate succession. And why is this?

original: smṛtisaṃskārayor ekarūpatvāt yathānubhavās tathā saṃskārāḥ / te ca karmavāsanānurūpāḥ
analyzed: smṛti saṃskārayoḥ eka rūpa tvāt yathā anubhavāḥ tathā saṃskārāḥ te ca karma vāsanā anurūpāḥ
translated: Because memory and impressions have the same form. The impressions are in accordance with the experience. And those are in accordance with the latent tendencies of karma.

original: yathā ca vāsanās tathā smṛtir iti jātideśakālavyavahitebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ smṛtiḥ /
analyzed: yathā ca vāsanāḥ tathā smṛtiḥ iti jāti deśa kāla vyavahitebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ smṛtiḥ
translated: And just as the impressions are, so is the memory. Thus memory arises from impressions separated by birth, place, and time.

original: smṛteś ca punaḥ saṃskārā ityevam ete smṛtisaṃskārāḥ karmāśayavṛttilābhavaśād vyajyante
analyzed: smṛteḥ ca punar saṃskārāḥ iti evam ete smṛti saṃskārāḥ karma āśaya vṛttilābha vaśāt vyajyante
translated: And from memory again arise impressions. Thus these memory-impressions are manifested by the power of the arising of the activity of the latent tendencies of karma.

original: ataś ca vyavahitānām api nimittanaimittikabhāvānucchedād ānantaryam eva siddham iti / /
analyzed: atas ca vyavahitānām api nimitta naimittika bhāva anucchedāt ānantaryam eva siddham iti
translated: And therefore, since the relation of cause and effect is not interrupted even for those that are separated, immediate succession is established.

original: tāsām anāditvaṃ cāśiṣo nityatvāt // / //
analyzed: tāsām anādi tvam ca āśiṣaḥ nitya tvāt
translated: And their beginninglessness is due to the eternality of desires.

original: tāsāṃ vāsanānām āśiṣo nityatvād anāditvam / yeyam ātmāśīr mā na bhūvaṃ bhūyāsam iti /sarvasya
analyzed: tāsām vāsanānām āśiṣaḥ nitya tvāt anādi tvam yā iyam ātma āśīḥ mā na bhūvam bhūyāsam iti sarvasya
translated: The beginninglessness of those latent impressions is due to the eternality of desires. The desire of the self, May I not be, may I be, is seen in all.

original: dṛśyate sā na svābhāvikī / kasmāt jātamātrasya jantor ananubhūtamaraṇadharmakasya
analyzed: dṛśyate sā na svābhāvikī kasmāt jāta mātrasya jantoḥ an anubhūta maraṇa dharmakasya
